characters: CASTLE AND RIVER BOAT AND JETTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY PLANTAGENET close up. His eyes are bright, his teeth bared in a grin of fierce excitement. The picture is frozen and the title remains as we pull back enough to see bright blue i sky, green field, with a festive Camelot-like little tent in the distance. HENRY, we now see, is ! poised for dueling, sword in hand. (HENRY is 50, an age at which, in his time, men were either old or dead. Not HENRY. very nearly all he ever was, he is enjoying that final rush of physical and mental vigor that comes to some men not before the end but just before the state of the decline. (As the title fades, the pictures starts to move and HENRY barks out - )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come on. Come for me. (He brings his sword down and the duel begins. His OPPONENT, whom we see from behind, charges at him, raining blow after blow. HENRY parries only, never striking back, always retreating. (They fight across the field. Suddenly, HENRY, moving backwards, trips and falls. With a cry, his OPPONENT charges at him. Effortlessly, HENRY strikes his first blow. The OPPONENT'S sword flies from his hand as he sprawls flat out on the ground. HENRY bounds to his feet, moves to his fallen opponent and looks down. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the OPPONENT from HENRY'S POV. It's JOHN, his son of 16, who, in 18 years, was to become the worst king in English history. Still pudgy with baby fat, he has a round open face that is enchanting when he smiles. He is frightened now and shaken up. (Cut to HENRY from JOHN'S POV. He glares down, sword in hand. Then, with a quick, gruff smile he reaches down and yanks JOHN to his feet) |

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're gaining on it, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Am I, Father? Am I really?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Off you go, now. Run along and practice. (JOHN picks up his sword, starts across the field toward a KNIGHT, his dueling master who stands waiting. HENRY, a look of affection on his face as he looks after JOHN, turns and starts across the field toward the little tent. He waves. We can just make out a figure by the tent. It waves j back.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to JOHN and the KNIGHT. JOHN casts a look in HENRY'S direction. There is no love lost. As he turns back and dueling practice begins - (Cut to tent. Food for a royal picnic is hand- somely arranged. The FIGURE we saw is a girl. HENRY lies, his head on her lap. (Cut to the GIRL, close up. ALAIS CAPET is 23 and exquisitely beautiful. She is like a fine porcelain figure - fragile, delicate, pure, the only person in this story easy to break. She is happily and desperately in love with HENRY; it's all over her as she looks down at him)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: (singing softly in her native tongue; bright and gay) Allons gai, gai, gai, bergere; allons gai Allons gai, soyez legere, suivez mois. (We pull back, including them both. HENRY'S gaze is out across the field)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He'll make a good king. He'll be ready. (Cut to JOHN & THE KNIGHT. JOHN flailing away stumbles and staggers about. Cut back to HENRY &

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: That's it, that's the way, lad.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Oh, what difference does it make who's king next? Does it matter who comes after you?  Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (He sits up, takes a chicken leg from a platter, starts devouring it) There is a legend of a King called Lear with whom I have in common. Both of us have kingdoms and three children we adore and both of us are old. But there it stops. He cut kingdom into bits. I can't do that. I've built an empire: of England, half of France. It all goes where I say it go and I say John. ALAIS i I'm going to lose you, Henry, aren't I? and novices, whores, gypsies, jades and little boys but n in God's western world have I found anyone to love but yo And Rosamund. She's dead.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: And Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The new medusa, my good wife.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: How is your queen?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Decaying, I suppose. No, don't be jealous of the gorgon; is not among the things I love. How many husbands do you who lock their wives away? I haven't kept the great bitch the keep for ten years out of passionate attachment. Ah - there's Captain Marshal.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Alais, in my time, I've known contessas, milkmaids, court

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: i (He sees something across the field) (He rises, beckons, calls) William. EXT. CASTLE ’ (Cut to full view of the field from beyond the ; tent. We are not in countryside at all but rather | just outside the great wall of a castle. Along the wall, SERVANTS, SOLDIERS and ATTENDANTS for the a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 Continued royal picnic stand at the ready. On horseback, riding past them toward Henry is WILLIAM MARSHAL. Cut to - (MARSHAL in close up. He is 35 and looks like the distinguished soldier he is. A rugged face but honest, open and friendly. He was totally devoted to Henry and his children and through all their wars and conflicts somehow managed always to be loyal to all of them. Cut to - (HENRY, aS MARSHAL stands before him, bowing)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We will be holding Christmas Court at Chinon. We have ask the King of France to join us. I want Richard there. And Geoffrey. Find my boys and tell them so. And then go fetc the Queen from Salisbury Tower.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: If the Queen refuses?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Eleanor? She wouldn't miss this for the world. (Cut to MARSHAL riding across the field away from the castle. Cut to - (HENRY & ALAIS standing side by side at the tent, watching him go)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's going to be a family Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I'm afraid, too.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What of?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Just afraid. (He looks at her with enormous tenderness, takes her in his arms. They hold each other. Cut to ~ (HENRY, close up, eyes closed, holding her. He opens his eyes, looks out across the field. Anxiety crosses his face. Cut to - (JOHN, sweating, red-faced, flailing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard! (TWO KNIGHTS on horse in full armor charging at each other with lances. One of the KNIGHTS is a giant of a man. They meet with tremendous impact. The GIANT KNIGHT is sent flying violently to the ground. (We are in the lists, watching a contest. It is not the set we're used to seeing - grandstands, canopies, banners. At this time, the lists consisted of the broad, shallow mud trench that lay between the inner and outer walls of a castle. It is primitive and crude, not glamorous. The audience either stands or sits on straw spread on the mud. There sit one or two crude benches for the most important nobles present. (The smaller KNIGHT, himself a large man, leaps from his horse, throws off his visor and we get our first look at RICHARD LIONHEART. (RICHARD, at 26, looks like his legend: handsome, impressive, fierce, powerful. He loves the blood and violence of war. He is caught up in this passion when we see him and his face is frightening. (He moves to the GIANT KNIGHT who lies stunned, sprawled in the mud. He draws his sword. He is going to kill the man. Cut to - (The audience. They are appalled but afraid to speak. Behind them, MARSHAL strides down toward the lists. Cut to - (RICHARD, sword poised. The GIANT KNIGHT stirs, making animal sounds of protest)

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: (Voice over, calling out) (RICHARD hesitates, turns. Cut to - (MARSHAL walking into the lists towards him. In ordinary, conversational tones) Hello, Richard. (CREDITS continues as we cut to - il EXT. CLIFFTOPS (A rocky sea coast. A large body of foot soldiers are marching along the shore. There is a cliff along the shore. The camera moves up it. There is a tiny movement at the top. The camera zooms in on -

dialogues.speaker: OC
dialogues.text: 11 12 13 Continued Geoffrey. (GEOFFREY PLANTAGENET, Count of Brittany, crouched in a clump of undergrowth. Geoffrey is 25, lithe, feline, attractive, quick of speech and movement. His was the best brain of a brainy family and his face shines with intelligence. Dressed for the palace, not the field, he is watching the progress of the troops below. (We see the field behind him. A large body of KNIGHTS in full armor on horse stand divided into two orderly groups, one some distance to his left, the other to his right. (GEOFFREY signals to one of the groups. We see them charge wildly down the cliff. They come down in front of the troops below. (The troops are thrown into wild confusion. They start to run in retreat. (GEOFFREY signals to his other group of KNIGHTS. Watches them roaring down the cliff, coming down again in front of retreating troops. The slaughter on the beech is terrible. (GEOFFREY watches it, feeling pleasure not at the slaughter, but at a maneuver well planned and executed. (MARSHAL appears on the field behind him, approaching)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (Turning to MARSHAL) Father wants to see me. (MARSHAL nods) Where and when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the Main Gate of the great castle. We are at Salisbury Tower. MARSHAL appears, striding toward the gate. As the gate begins to open for him, cut to -)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smaller gate in the castle yard. SOLDIERS on guard duty in front of it. MARSHAL approaches. The gate is opened. Cut to -)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 14 15 INT. INT. Your majesty. There is to be a Christmas Court. yes,

dialogues.speaker: SALISBURY TOWER DOORWAY
dialogues.text: (A heavily barred doorway inside the tower, TWO GUARDS duty. They come to attention as MARSHAL appears. As they open the gate, cut to - {A large, cold, relatively barren castle room. A few chairs, wooden chests, a bed, a few wall tapestries, straw on the floor. Even when we come to Chinon, all the rooms are like this. Luxury and elegance did not exist. The only richness of the period was in the fabrics of the clothes the wealthy wore)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR'S ROOM SALISBURY TOWER '
dialogues.text: madam. (The camera takes in the room. A GUARD stands by r the room's one door. He is a young and splendid looking soldier except for the fact that his left arm, at a point just above the elbow, has been lost in combat. In one corner of the room, there are two Maids-in-waiting doing needlework by the small : window. We come finally to a fireplace. There is } a blazing fire. There is an armchair by the fire. i In it sits - (ELEANOR OF AQUITAINE. She is 61 and looks nothing like it. She is a truly handsome woman of great temperament, authority and presence. She has been a Queen of international importance for 46 years and you know it. Finally, she is that most unusual thing: a genuinely feminine woman thoroughly capable of holding her own in a man's world. (When we first see her, she is gazing into the fire, deep in thought. there is no sense of repose; this is not reverie. The eyes burn and the mind is busy. (We are looking past her, towards the door. It opens. The one-armed GUARD comes to attention as MARSHAL enters and bows)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Not turning. We move closer and closer to her face)

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: (Voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Where? (Nothing but her face. The look is enigmatic but the excitement is unmistakable)

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: At Chinon. (At the word 'Chinon,' cut from ELEANOR, close up to -)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (HENRY close up. He is asleep in bed. The camera draws back and we see ALAIS next to him. She is awake, motionless. She hasn't slept. We keep on drawing back, taking in - (HENRY'S room. Bare, cold, undecorated. Chairs, chests, tables - all heavy wood and crude - tapestries. Clothes are hung in the open from a pole that runs along the wall.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We continue drawing back, moving through a window to the outside. We take in the castle at Chinon bit by bit. First the tower we have just left, then the courtyard, then other buildings, then the outer wall, then the surrounding countryside and the broad River Vienne beyond the castle. (It is just before dawn. There is no sound. Nothing moves. It is cold. The fields are rimmed with frost. Everything looks black and white. (Suddenly, the first ray of the rising sun hits the top of the highest tower. Cut to -) (The bell in the chapel tower, close up, just as its clapper comes crashing down. The sound is deafening. Cut to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (HENRY as his eyes fly open. The bell continues tolling as HENRY, bursting with energy, sits bolt upright in bed, throws the covers off and bounds up. It was the universal custom of the time to sleep naked and there is a glimpse of bodies as

dialogues.speaker: QO
dialogues.text: 19 20 Continued HENRY throws a great fur-lined over his shoulders and ALAIS retrieves the blankets and covers herself. It is cold in the room. We can see their breath. Cut to - (HENRY seated on the bed, tugging heavy woolen tights on. Cut to - (ALAIS, sitting up now, blankets clutched around her, looking at him. She hesitates. Then -)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Henry, what if, just for once, I didn't do as I was told. (Cut to HENRY. Half dressed, he stands by a table. There is a wash bowl full of water on it, a thin film of ice on the water)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (As he breaks the ice, splashes water on his face) It's going to be a jungle of a day. If I start growling n I'll never last. {Cut to ALAIS on the bed, robe over her shoulders, starting to dress)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: you'll last. You're like the rocks at Stonehenge. Nothing knocks you down.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Drying his face with a towel) In these rooms, Alais, on this Christmas, I have all the enemies I need.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You have more than you think.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Are you one? Has my willow turned to poison oak?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: If I decided to be trouble, Henry, how much trouble could

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY & ALAIS, dressed now, moving down a corridor. They pass an occasional SERVANT who

dialogues.speaker: 20X1
dialogues.text: 10 Continued stops and bows. We follow them as HENRY strides briskly along, ALAIS half-running to keep up)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I could give away your plans.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You don't know what they are.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I know you want to disinherit Richard.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So does Eleanor. She knows young Henry's dead. The Young died in summer and I haven't named an heir. She knows I w John on the throne and I know she wants Richard. We are v frank about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY & ALAIS at a table eating breakfast. They eat, as was the custom, with spoons and fingers from a common bowl that sits on the table between them)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Henry, I can't be your mistress if I'm married to your so

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why can't you? Johnny wouldn't mind.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I do not like your Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He's a good boy. ;

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: He's got pimples and he smells of compost.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He's just sixteen; he can't help the pimples.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: He could bathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY striding briskly down a corridor, ALAIS hurrying after him. The corridor is more crowded now. There are KNIGHTS and HIGH CLERGYMEN who, as HENRY passes, stop and bow. HENRY ignores it all, striding on until - (He reaches a niche in the corridor. He stops abruptly, turns on ALAIS)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It isn't such a dreadful thing to be a Queen of England. all eyes will weep for you.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Will yours?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't know. very likely.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: All I want is not to lose you. Can't you hide me? Can't I simply disappear.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You know you can't. Your little brother Philip's King of France now and he wants your wedding or your dowry back. only took you for your dowry. You were seven; two big kne and two big eyes and that's all. How was I to know? (We pull back as HENRY moves to kiss her lightly. There is a sound of running down the corridor. It's JOHN. He slows down as he sees his father and fiancee kissing. He doesn't like it. (Sensing someone. HENRY turns, takes JOHN in)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What's wrong, lad?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Producing a smile) Nothing. (With a skip and a wave, JOHN resumes running down the corridor. We follow him as he turns a corner, reaches a great high door, tugs it open, slips through and starts racing down a broad exterior flight of steps into the castle yard.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: (Calling, moving, excited and happy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We see the yard from JOHN'S POV. GEOFFREY, on horseback, is riding toward us. He waves back. The yard is a mob scene, crammed with SOLDIERS, SERVANTS, PEASANTS, tents, outdoor kitchens, livestock, poultry, horses, the lot. The SOLDIERS are lined up for morning chow. (JOHN threads his way through it all, reaching GEOFFREY as he dismounts)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (As they hug each other roughly) Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (A large bundle hangs from GEOFFREY'S saddle. Pointing to it) Is that for me? (GEOFFREY nods) I love Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to an enormous Christmas tree, close up, as it is being raised to standing position. (Pull back to see HENRY nodding at the tree in brisk approval. ALAIS stands near him, wanting to speak but hesitant. We are in the Parlor, a fairly spacious place which functioned as a kind of Family Room. There are the usual tapestries, some furniture, a desk and scattered about, piles of holly boughs. (HENRY turns to leave the room. ALAIS stops him, saying

dialogues.speaker: " ALAIS
dialogues.text: What difference does my dowry make? Let Philip have it ba It isn't much.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can't. The Vexin is a little country but it's vital to

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: And I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: ‘It's been my luck to fall in love with landed women. Whe married I thought: "You lucky man. The richest woman in t world. She owns the Aquitaine, the greatest province on t Continent -- and beautiful as well." She was, you know. a |

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: f*. 13 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: And you adored her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Memory fails. There may have been an era when I did. (As he arranges a loose lock of her hair) Let's have one strand askew; nothing in life has nay busi perfect. If I say you and I are done, we're done. If I sa marry John, it's John. I'll have you by me and I'll use y as I like. ,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to JOHN and GEOFFREY in the courtyard. There is a great clatter of horse's hooves behind them. they stop and turn. Cut to - (RICHARD arriving in the yard at full gallop. He reins in with great bravado and leaps from his horse. Cut to - (GEOFFREY starting toward RICHARD with a friendly wave of greeting. JOHN, glaring sullenly at RICHARD, hangs back, then follows GEOFFREY. Cut to - (RICHARD, JOHN & GEOFFREY crossing the courtyard toward the stables. RICHARD leads his horse)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Ah, Christmas; warm and rosy time. The hot wine steams, t Yule it roars and we're the fat that's in the fire. She'l here soon, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Mother.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Does she still want you to be king?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We are not as friendly as we were.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: If I'm supposed to make a fuss and kiss her hairy cheek, won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 26 27 14 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What you kiss, little prince, is up to you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm Father's favorite; that's what counts.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (Stopping, looking down at JOHN, with quiet, total conviction) You hardly know me, Johnny, so I beg you to believe my reputation. I'm a constant soldier and a sometime poet an I will be King.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Just you remember: Father loves me best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY & ALAIS. He is seated at a desk, busily going through state papers)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Why John? John doesn't care for you at all.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We love each other deeply.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: None of them has any love for you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Because we fight? Tell me they all three want the crown, tell you it's a feeble prince that doesn't. They may snap me and plot and that makes them the kind of sons I want. snapped and plotted all my life. There is no other way to King, alive and fifty all alone.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I'm going to fight for you. f ‘HENRY Oh, fine. EXT. BATTLEMENTS i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the walk that runs along the top of the castle wall. HENRY is pacing impatiently, repeatedly looking out in expectation toward the River Vienne that runs quite near, below them. ALAIS, with great determination is saying -)  27 15 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: When I was sixteen and we started this depraved relations left everything to you. I lap sat, drank my milk and did I was told. Not any more. Your cherub's twenty-three now she's going to fight.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: With mace and chain?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: With anything that I can think of.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I need another mind at work. Try: you hear the thinking through the walls. There's Geoffrey's h and Richard's roar, and Eleanor, she's always wrapped in thoughts, like molten lead and marble slabs. My house is of intellectual activity.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Add mine.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Going to her, gruff but tender) Alais, Alais -- I don't plan to give you up. I don't plan give you anything. I'11 make alliances and bargains, thre beg, break heads and hearts and when I'm done, I'll make heir of John, a petty prince of Richard and I'11l still h you.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: When can I believe you, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Always; even when I lie.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: But with so many enemies --

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I know -- and some of them are brighter folk that I or cr or more ruthless or dishonest. But not all rolled in one. priests write all the history these days and they'll do m justice. Henry, they'll say, was a master bastard. (Pointing excitedly down toward the river) Look.

dialogues.speaker: CASTLE AND RIVER BOAT AND JETTY
dialogues.text: (Cut to a boat as it rounds a bend in the river near the castle) (Cut to ELEANOR on the desk of the boat. MARSHAL stands near her, The one-armed GUARD on duty, stands stiffly in the background. Eleanor's two Maids-in-waiting stand near him.)

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: (Cut to.HENRY, close up, as he hurries down stone castle steps. His face is lit with a sense of eagerness and anticipation that have nothing to do with affection.

dialogues.speaker: BOAT AND RIVER
dialogues.text: (Cut to ELEANOR on the deck. The boat is near the dock now. Her face is alive with suppressed excitement. She pats her hair, finds it in order, anxiously tugs at her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY striding through the turmoil of the castle yard. Far behind him, ALAIS hurries after)

dialogues.speaker: CASTLE RIVER, BOAT AND JETTY
dialogues.text: (Cut to SAILORS catching ropes, mooring the boat to the dock. (Cut to HENRY plunging through the mud and debris along the dock. (Cut to ELEANOR, very regal and formal, at the top of the gangplank. We draw back, seeing HENRY stationed at the bottom. With stately movement, ELEANOR comes down the plank. HENRY stands waiting as, reaching him, she bows and kisses his hand.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How was your crossing? Did the Channel part for you?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It went flat when I told it to. I didn't think to ask for more. How dear of you to let me out of jail.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's only for the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 17 30X1 Continued 31 32 33

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Like school. You keep me young. (They turn, start up the dock toward the castle. She sees ALAIS)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Here's gentle Alais. (ALAIS starts to curtsy) No, no; greet me as you used to. (She takes ALAIS into her arms, holding her lightly. Fragile I am not; affection is a pressure I can bear. (As she releases ALAIS, she looks up toward the castle.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the castle from ELEANOR'S POV. JOHN, - RICHARD & GEOFFREY are standing there, by the Main Gate. (Cut to ELEANOR. Pleased and proud) Oh, but I do have handsome children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to ELEANOR, close up, as she busses JOHN on the cheek. We pull back and see that they are in the Parlour.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: John -- you're so clean and neat. Henry takes good care o you. (She moves to RICHARD, kisses him lightly) And Richard. Don't look sullen, dear. It makes your eyes small and piggy and your chin look weak. Is Philip here y

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Let's hope he's grown up like his father -- simon pure an simon simple. Good, good Louis; if I'd managed sons for h instead of all those little girls, I'd still be Queen of and we should not have known each other. Such, my angels, the role of sex in history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 Continued OQ (Great flourishes on horns and trumpets are heard from the castle yard)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That will be Philip. (She' turns and starts toward the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to a broad hallway by a large closed door. ELEANOR is just reaching the door, RICHARD, JOHN & GEOFFREY strung out behind her)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Looking about expectantly) Where's Henry?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Upstairs with the family whore.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That is a mean and tawdry way to talk about your fiancee.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: OQ My fiancee.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Whoever fiancee, I brought her up and she is dear to me a gentle.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: He still plans to make John king.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Of course he does. My, what a greedy little trinity you a king, king, king. Two of you must learn to live with disappointment. (Cut to HENRY as he strides toward them)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Ah, but which two?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Let's deny them all and live forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tusk to tusk through all eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 Continued (TWO SERVANTS approach bearing a crown and a great formal cloak. Briskly, to his boys, as he shrugs into the cloak and slaps the crown on) HENRY (Cont) The King of France and I will shortly have a tactile conv tion like two surgeons looking for a lump. We'll state positions and I'll make the first of many offers. He'll r it, naturally, I'll make a better one and so on through t holidays until I win. For the duration of this joyous rit you will give, to your father, your support. (With which he wheels toward the door. The TWO SERVANTS throw it open and HENRY, the others following, strides toward into the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the courtyard from their POV. We see a very grand and formal state occasion. NOBLES & CLERGYMEN stand in formal ranks along the broad descending steps. All the COMMONFOLK have lined up, as commonfolk always do, along the edges of a broad aisle. SOLDIERS at attention, line the aisle. (Down the aisle marches a gorgeous, stately retinue of KNIGHTS & SOLDIERS. At their head is Philip, King of France. (PHILIP CAPET is 18 years old and absolutely gorgeous. He is tall, well-proportioned and handsome without being at all pretty. His manner is open, direct, simple and strikingly authoritative. He has been King of France for three years and has learned a lot. (PHILIP mounts the steps, stands before HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (As they greet each other) My lord.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Your grace.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Welcome to Chinon. (More horns and Trumpets as HENRY turns and bows through the doorway. As the procession moves into the castle, we cut to -)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The door of the parlor, seen from inside the room. The door opens, HENRY again bows PHILIP through, then HENRY and ELEANOR follow. There is a general change of manner, from formal to informal as RICHARD, GEOFFREY, JOHN & ALAIS follow into the room)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Taking off a formal robe, feeling more comfortable) Well, that's better.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (To PHILIP) I was told you were impressive for a boy of eighteen. I'm Eleanor, who might have been your mother. All the others you know.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: (Bowing) Queen Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Informal, settling himself comfortably in a chair) I gather you're disturbed about your sister and her dowry

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: (Standing before him, stiff and formal) Sixteen years ago, you made a treaty with us. It is time terms were executed. The scene, through most of the following exchange between Philip and Henry, is a domestic one. ALAIS passes along them with a tray of drinks and hors d'oeuvres. ELEANOR settles comfortable, taking some needlework from a bag and works on it. JOHN busies himself decking the hall with boughs of holly. GEOFFREY, finding the hors d'oeuvres delicious, settles by a table that holds an assortment of them. Only RICHARD fails to relax. He stands apart from all of them, suspicious and hostile)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I should think so.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Our position comes to this: that you either hold the marr or return the vexin. Alais marries Richard or we'll have county back at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: omega Fi 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That's clear, concise and well presented. My position is well, frankly Philip, it's a tangle. (As he rises and moves to RICHARD, all affability) Two years ago, the Queen and I, for reasons passing under standing, gave the Aquitaine to Richard. That makes Richa very powerful. How can I give him Alais, too? The man she marries has you for an ally.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: It's their wedding or the Vexin back. Those are the terms made with Louis.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Moving to PHILIP. Just the two of them now) True but academic, lad. The vexin's mine.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: By what authority?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's got my troops all over it: that makes it mine. Now h me, boy --

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I am a king: I'm no man's boy. HENRY. A king? Because you put your ass on purple cushions?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Sir. (He turns on his heel, starts for the door) (Cut to HENRY & ELEANOR as they exchange amused glances )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Philip, you haven't got the feel of this at all. Use all voices. When I bellow, bellow back.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I'll mark that down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Moving close to PHILIP) This, too. We are the world in small. A nation is a human thing. It does what we do, for our reasons. Surely, if we civilized, it must be possible to put the knives away. We make peace. We have it in our hands.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I've tutors of my own. Will that be all?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh, think. You came here for a reason. Don't you want to me if I've got an offer?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Have you got an offer?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Not yet -- but I'll think of one. (PHILIP is half out the door. Voice over) Oh, by the way ... (PHILIP turns. Cut to HENRY, smiling agreeably) You're better at this than I thought you'd be. (Cut to PHILIP smiling agreeably back)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I wasn't sure you'd noticed. (Cut to HENRY as PHILIP goes. HENRY turns, taking in his family. (Cut to HENRY'S POV. We see JOHN with holly, ELEANOR with her needle, GEOFFREY licking his fingers, ALAIS serving more wine and RICHARD glowering. (Cut to HENRY as he makes a friendly, expansive gesture)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well -- what shall be hang: The holly or each other?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (Moving into the picture) Would you say, Father, that I have the makings of a King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 23 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: A splendid King.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Would you expect me, Father, to give up without a fight?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: O£ course you'll fight. I raised you to.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don't care what you offer Philip. I don't care what pla you make. I'll have the Aquitaine and Alais and the crown won't give up one to get the other. I won't trade off Ala the Aquitaine to this - (He gestures toward JOHN. Cut to JOHN. VOICE over) -- this walking pustule. (Cut from JOHN'S outrage back to RICHARD) No, your loving son will not. (As he turns to go, cut to JOHN who rushes up to

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Did you hear what he called me?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Clearly, dear. Now run along. It's nearly dinnertime.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I only do what Father tells me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Go and eat.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Did I say something wrong? I'm always saying something wr

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Don't pout.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 36 24 Continued

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Pouting) I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Giving him a slap on the butt) And stand up straight. How often do I have to tell you? (JOHN scurries toward the door. Cut to - (HENRY, the exasperated parent. Cut to - (ELEANOR, gazing with amusement at HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And that's to be the king.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: And I'm to be his Chancellor. Has he told you? John will there while I run it. That's to say, he gets to spend the taxes that I get to him.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How nice for you.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: It's not as nice as being king.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We've made you Duke of Brittany. Is that so little?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: No one ever thinks of crown and mentions Geoff. What is t

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Isn't being Chancellor power enough?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: It isn't power that I feel deprived of; it's the mention miss. There's no affection for me here. You wouldn't thin I'd want that, would you? (He is going as he says this. Cut to ELEANOR bleakly watching him go. ‘ELEANOR Henry, I have a confession.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Voice over) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I don't much like our children. (Rising, moving toward ALAIS) Only you. The child I raised but didn't bear.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You never cared for me.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I did and do. Believe me, Henry's bed is Henry's province can people it with sheep for all I care. Which, on occasi he has done. (Cut to HENRY. The subject of Rosamund is clearly a raw nerve)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Still that? When Rosamund's been dead for seven years. (Cut back to ELEANOR & ALAIS)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: He found Miss Clifford in the mists of Wales and brought for closer observation. Liking what he saw, he scrutinize many years. He loved her deeply and she him. And yet, my when Henry had to choose between his lady and my lands ..

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: There is no sport in hurting me. It is so easy.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: After all the years of love and care, do you think I coul bring myself to hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Eleanor, with both hands tied behind you. (As she turns to go, cut to HENRY. His concern for ALAIS is clearly on his face. Cut to - (ELEANOR gazing fondly and sadly after her. Cut back to - (HENRY as he adjusts his expression for ELEANOR's

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: If I'd chosen, who could I have picked to love to gall yo more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Smiling up at him) There's no one. Come on; let's finish Christmassing the p (She moves to a pile of ornaments on a table by the Christmas tree. Through the following, like any Moin and they decorate the tree. Much care is devoted to placing the proper ornament just so, glancing at each other for reaction to the decorating, shakes and nods of heads.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Time hasn't done a thing but wrinkle you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It hasn't even done that. I have borne six girls, five bo and thirty-one connubial years of you. How am I possible?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There are moments when I miss you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (They pause, smiling fondly at each other. Then, reaching out and tousling his hair) That's my woolly sheep dog. So wee Johnny gets the crown.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've heard it rumored but I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Losing Alais will be hard, for you do love her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's an old man's last attachment; nothing more. How hard you find living in your castle?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It was difficult in the beginning but that's past. I find seen the world enough.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'll never let you loose. You led too many civil wars aga me.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And I damn near won the last one. Still, as long as I get trotted out for Christmas Courts and state occasions now then, for I do like to see you, it's enough. (She steps back, surveys the tree) I think that's all the Christmassing this thing can stand famished. Let's go in to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 37 27 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Extending his arm) Arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And hand in hand. (She takes his arm. They start out of the room) You're still a marvel of a man.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: And you're my lady. (They move arm in arm to the door. His hand on the knob, HENRY pauses, turns) It's an odd thing, Eleanor. I've fought and bargained all these years as the only thing I lived for was what happen after I was dead. I've something else to live for now. I' blundered on to peace.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Wry amusement on her face) On Christmas Eve.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Since Louis died, while Philip grew, I've had no France t fight. And in lull, I've found how good it is to write a or make a tax more fair or in judgment to decide which pe gets a cow. There is, I tell you, nothing more important the world. And now the French boy's big enough and I am s of war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He opens the door, moves into the corridor. She follows. We go with them down the hallway. It is dimly lit by smoky wall torches. The corridor is empty except for occasional quietly prowling dogs. Castles at the time were full of dogs and throughout the film, the animals are everywhere)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Do you still need the vexin, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's as crucial as it ever was. My troops there are a day from Paris, just a march of twenty miles. I must keep it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Henry, dear, if Alais doesn't marry Richard, I will see y lose the vexin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued (They stop outside a large double door)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well, I thought you'd never say it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You can try. (A SERVANT appears, moves to the door) We've got a pack of barons we should look the loving coup for.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (smiling a terrible smile at him) Can you read love in that?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: And permanent affection. (The door is opened. They start forward. Cut to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The castle's Great Hall from their Pov. It is an enormous high ceilinged, stone walled room. Long trestle tables along the length of it. NOBLES & CLERGYMEN sit on benches at the tables. COURT MUSICIANS & ENTERTAINERS are poised on a platform at one side. SERVANTS stand forward at serving tables piled high with food. The royal table is at the far end of the hall on a platform. PHILIP, RICHARD, GEOFFREY, JOHN & ALAIS are there. (The hall is heated by a huge fire that blazes on the stones in the center of the room. Some of the smoke rises to escape from a hole in the ceiling. Torches are everywhere. The smoke is terrible. There is much howling from a multitude of dogs. (As HENRY. & ELEANOR more into the hall, the ORCHESTRA plays a fanfare and EVERYBODY rises.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (As she and HENRY make their stately way down the long hall to their table. Nodding to this NOBLE, smiling at that. My Richard is the next king, not your John. I know you, H I know every twist and bend you've got and I'll be waitin round each corner to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Do you truly care who's king?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I care because you care so much.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Don't fight me, Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What would you have me do? Give out, give up, give in?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Give me a little peace.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: A little? Why so modest? How about eternal peace? Now there's a thought.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: If you oppose me, I will strike you any way I can. (They have reached their table. Their eyes are locked; HENRY'S cold with warning, ELEANOR'S bright with defiance. (The pose breaks and they sit. SERVANTS appear by each of them with bowls of water and towels. They start to wash their hands. Then - )

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (She leans toward HENRY. They are close enough to kiss) Henry?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Madam?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Did you ever love me?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Good. That will make this pleasanter. (She sits back, wipes her hands. We draw away from her taking in more and more of the hall until we see all of it - the bustle and smoke, the howling and shouting, the music and caroling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 30 Continued (This point of punctuation in the story. All opening positions have been taken, all challenges made. It should be the first slow fade in the filn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We see a Christmas package on a table. Hands are tying a ribbon around it. We pull back to see ELEANOR seated at a table in her room. Behind her is a door. It opens. RICHARD steps through. Behind him in the corridor, the one-armed GUARD closes the door. RICHARD stays by the doorway, looking at his mother. She is aware that he's there but goes on wrapping the package. RICHARD moves from the doorway toward her, saying

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: All right, I've come. I'm here. What was it you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Just to talk. We haven't been alone, the two of us in -- long is a lamb? Two years? You look fit. War agrees with you. I keep informed. I follow all your slaughters from a distance. Do sit down.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Is this an audience, a good night hug with kisses or an a

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Let us hope it's a reunion. Must you look so stern? I sen for you to say I want your love again but I can't say it face like that.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: My love, of all thing. What would you want it for?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Why, for itself. What other purpose could I have?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: If I were you, I'd try another tack. I have no damned up floods of passion for you. There's no chance I'll overflo

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You are a dull boy. Dull as plainsong: la, la, la, foreve one note. I gave the Church up out of boredom. I can do a much for you. RICHARD . You'll never give me up - not while I hold the Aquitaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You think I'm motivated by a love of real estate.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I think you want it back. You're so deceitful you can't a for water while you're thirsty. We could tangle spiders i webs you weave.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: If I'm so devious, why don't you go? Don't stand there quivering in limbo. Love me, little lamb, or leave me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (Not moving) Leave you, Madam? With pure joy.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Departure is a simple act. You put the left foot down and the right. (JOHN runs into the room, excited in high spirits. GEOFFREY follows him)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Mother --

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Hush, dear. Mother's fighting.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Father's finished working out the treaty terms.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Getting to her feet) How nice. Where is your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY. He is outside in a corner of the courtyard, busy distributing Christmas largesse to the deserving poor. ALAIS is with him. A SERVANT follows them along, pulling a car filled with roast geese, pastries and such. (They are in front of a row of wooden hovels that line the stone castle wall. Gardeners, poultry keepers, smiths and armorers live in these huts. We see them receiving goodies with bows and smiles. (It is late afternoon and cold. The shadows are sharp and clear. Activity in the yard, when we see it, is slight. SOLDIERS & PEASANTS are settling down by tiny fires, eating and drinking. From

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 Continued across the yard comes the sound of carolers caroling)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Voice over) There you are. (HENRY & ALAIS turn. Cut to - (ELEANOR from HENRY'S POV. Wearing a heavy robe, she is crossing the yard toward them. RICHARD, JOHN & GEOFFREY come along behind her.) ELEANOR (Cont) Well -- have you put the terms to Philip?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Not yet, but we're shortly granting him an audience. I ho you'll all attend.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Are we to know the terms or would you rather tease us?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (He stops handing out food, moves away from the huts and people toward an area where livestock is kept) Not at all. The terms are these:

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What are you giving up to Philip? What of mine?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Whatever you've got goes to me.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: And what's the nothing Geoffrey gets?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: For God's sake, boys, you can't all three be kings.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: All three of us can try.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That's pointless now. I want you to succeed me, Richard. Alais and the crown: I give you both.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I've got no sense of humor. If I did, I'd laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I mean to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What about me? I'm your favorite, I'm the one you love.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: John, I can't help myself. (He takes JOHN, moves him next to RICHARD. JOHN scowls up, RICHARD glowers down) HENRY (Cont) Could you keep anything I gave you? Could you beat him on field?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Scurrying to his father) You could.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But John, I won't be there. I'm losing, too. All of my dr for you are lost.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You've led me on.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I never meant to.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (The tears start to come) You're a failure as a father, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (He sinks down to the frozen ground, a sorry little heap. Pigs peer at him curiously from the enclosure just behind him) Not yet you're not. But I'll do something terrible and yo be sorry then. (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Did you rehearse all this or are you improvising?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Good God, woman, face the facts.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Which ones? We've got so many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 34 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Power is the only fact. How can I keep him from the crown He's only take it if I didn't give it to him. (He turns to RICHARD, glowering)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No - you'd make me fight to get it. I know you. You'd nev give me everything -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: True; and I haven't. You get Alais and you get the kingdo I get the one thing I want most. If you're King, England intact. I get that. It's all yours now -- the girl, the crown, the whole black bloody business. Isn't that enough (HENRY turns and storms away across the courtyard. The caroling resumes. (The little group stands by the pig sty, watching HENRY go. No one moves until -)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I don't know who's to be congratulated. Not me, certainly (She looks at them, eyes bright with anger) Kings, Queens, knights everywhere you look and I'm the on pawn. I haven't got a thing to lose. That makes me danger (At the brink of tears, she turns and runs away from them -- not after HENRY but in another direction)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (voice over as we watch ALAIS running) Poor child. (Cut to JOHN suffering at the pig sty)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Poor John -- who says poor John? Don't everybody sob at o My God, if I went up in flames, there's not a living soul pee on me to put the fire out. (Cut to RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Let's strike a flint and see.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Getting to his feet as we see the whole group) He hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wo 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: For whatever I have done to you, forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What could you have done? You were never close enough.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: When you were little, you were torn from me: blame Henry.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I was torn from you by midwives and I haven't seen you si

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Then blame me if it helps.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No, it's the midwives' fault. They threw the baby out and the afterbirth.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Softly, from the heart, the absolute truth) You're everything a little brother dreams of, you know th used to dream about you all the time.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Arms open) Oh, Johnny ...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Longing to go to her) That's right, Mother. Mother me.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: yes, if you'd let me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Let you? Let you put your arms around me just the way you never did? {They are close) You can do it. Think I'm Richard. (Tenderly, she holds him. Close to breaking) That's it. That's the way. Now kiss my scabby cheek and r your fingers through my hair.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Filled suddenly with love for the boy) John, John ...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (It's more than he can bear. Wrenching away) No --! (Fighting back the tears) I'll show you, Eleanor. I haven't lost yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 Continued (He starts to move off with dignity but can't keep it up. Bursting into tears, he breaks into a run. i (ELEANOR, RICHARD & GEOFFREY start moving thoughtfully across the yard, past squatting figures, small groups of SOLDIERS drinking. Dogs bar. The wind blows)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Well, Mummy, if you want me, here I am.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: John's lost a Chancellor, has he?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: And you've gained one.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It is a bitter thing your Mummy has to say.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: She doesn't trust me. (They stop by a stone well in the yard. GEOFFREY perches on it. RICHARD, always wary, stands apart. In the distance, CAROLERS appear, singing something jolly)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You must know Henry isn't through with John. He'll keep t Vexin till the moon goes blue from cold and as for Richar wedding day, we'll see the second coming first; the needl alone can last for years.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: I know. You know I know, I know you know I know, we know Henry knows and Henry knows we know it. We're a knowledge family. Will Richard take me for his Chancellor or won't

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Why are you dropping John?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: He can't win -- but you can, with me to help you. I can h John. He'll swallow anything I tell him and I'1l take him i the hand and walk him into the trap you set. |

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're good, you're first class, Geoff. You'd sell John o me or me to John or -- you can tell me -- have you found CO way of selling everyone to everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nn 40 41 37 Continued

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Not yet, Mummy, but I'm working on it. I don't care who's King, but you and Henry do. I want to watch the two of yo picnicking on one another.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're as dull as Richard. We can use you. I like using people I can count on. Be our Chancellor.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: What? And miss the fun of selling you? (He starts off, turns back, spits it at her) Madam, may you rot.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Close up, watching him go. A spasm of regret and loss crosses her face) Oh, Geoffrey. (Bleakly, as she starts walking again, across the yard toward a low stone wall) Well, that's how deals are made. We've got him if we want He will sell us all, you know, but only if he thinks we t he won't. Why did I have to have such clever children? (They reach the wall, stopping before a small wooden door. She opens the door, moves through and we see - )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A small, cloistered herb garden. It is a perfectly beautiful place; small formal beds of rich frozen earth, delicate arches and columns along the walls, graceful stone benches. Distant hills rise high and stark beyond the far wall. The sun, a perfect faint orange ball, floats just above the hill-tops. Occasionally, scraps of caroling come floating to us. it is a setting of great gentleness and peace. (ELEANOR settles on a bench, looks up at her son)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Richard?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's a heavy thing, your nothing. When I write or send fo or speak or reach, your nothings come. Like stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don't play a scene with me.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I wouldn't if I could. I'm simpler than I used to be. I h at one time, many appetites. I wanted poetry and power an young men who create them both. I even wanted Henry, too, those days. Now, I've only one desire left: to see you Ki

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The only thing you want to see is Father's vitals on a be lettuce. You don't care who wins as long as Henry loses. You'd do anything. You are Medea to the teeth but this is son you won't use for vengeance on your husband. (ELEANOR rises, moving away from the vehemence of it. She moves to the low wall, stands looking out)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How my captivity has changed you. Henry meant to hurt me he's hacked you up instead. (Her hands rest on the top of the wall. They catch her eye. She raises the hand, looks at it) Men coveted this talon once. Henry was eighteen when we m and I was Queen of France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The camera rises, higher and higher. As she goes on speaking, we see the two of them in the lovely frozen garden from high above. (Then shifting slowly, we begin to see the country- [ side beyond the wall. There are little scattered ; houses, small farms, neat fields. Here, a horse E moves down a black dirt path, drawing a wagon; there a group of young people -- children and adolescents -- are skating on a frozen pond. (We move closer to the young people, near enough to. see how happy, young and beautiful they are. I Through all this -) ELEANOR (Cont) He came down from the North to Paris with a mind like Aristotle's and a form like mortal sin. We shattered the Commandments on the spot. I spent three months annulling and in Spring, in May not far from here, we married. Youn Count Henry and his countess. But in three years' time, I his Queen and he was King of England. Done at twenty-one. Five years your junior, General.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (We see them both) I can count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Not doubt the picture of your parents being fond does not in your gallery, but we were fond. There was no Thomas Be then, or Rosamund. No rivals - (Cut to ELEANOR, close up) - only me. And then Young Henry came and you and all the blossoms in my garden. (Looking straight at him. We see them both) yes, if I'd been sterile darling, I'd be happier today.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Is that designed to hurt me?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What a waste. I've fought with Henry over who comes next, whose dawn it is and which son gets the sunset and we'll live to see it. Look at you. I loved you more than Henry it's cost me everything.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I want us back the way we were.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That's not it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: All right, then. I want the Aquitaine.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Now that's the Mother I remember.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: We can win. I can get you Alais. I can make the marriage happen - but I've got to have the Aquitaine to do it. I m have it back.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It's mine. I'll never give it up.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'll write my will. "To Richard, everything." Would you believe me then? (She starts to go) Where's paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Paper burns.

dialogues.speaker: . ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And tears and turns to pudding in the rain. What can I do (He glares at her) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You love nothing. You are incomplete. The human parts of are missing. You're as dead as you are deadly. (The pain on her face is real and deep) You were lovely once. I've seen the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, don't you remember how you loved me? We were always h in hand. (She thrusts her hand in his) That's how it felt.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: As coarse and hot as that. (She snatches her hand away and bares her forearm. A small knife is suddenly in her other hand)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: This won't burn. I'll scratch a will on this. To Richard; everything. (She draws the knife across the flesh. We see the blood)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Mother. (Her arms are open. He comes into them)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Softly, as they hold each other) Mother.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: See? You do remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 42 43 4l Continued (We draw back from them. We see the garden and the hills beyond. The sun touches the scene with the last warmth of the day and dips behind the hills) I taught you dancing, too, and languages and all the musi I knew and how to love what's beautiful. The sun was warm then and we were every day together. (They stand in silhouette. We hear a wisp of caroling and the blowing of the wind. Fade out. (Cut in, sharp, loud and bright, on HENRY in close up. He is roaring with laughter. We hear other voices laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We are in the Great Hall. The dining tables have been removed and the benches rearranged. Seated on them are the NOBLES & CLERICS. They are watching - (A pantomime. TWO ACTORS -- A LECHEROUS OLD MAN and a DELICIOUS SERVANT GIRL -- are doing a bawdy love scene. He lusts for her. Pretending to resist she eggs him on. With a great heave, he tears open the bosom of her dress. About to dive in, he turns. They freeze. We see the WIFE. She is a vast old battleaxe. She holds a vast old battleaxe. She raises it. Cut back to HENRY who - (Gesturing toward WILLIAM MARSHAL who stands a few paces behind him, says - )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: William. (MARSHAL moves to him) Tell the French King I'll receive him in the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Yes, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: In half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to PHILIP. He is seated at a table, playing chess)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Half an hour. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Continued (We pull back to see GEOFFREY seated at the table with him. They are in a small, quiet chamber by an open fire. MARSHAL bows and goes)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (He makes a move, then says in the most conversational way) Of course, you know there's not a word of truth to Henry' terms.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: If that's a warning, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: What if it's an offer?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: “What if" is a game for scholars: what if angels sat on pinheads.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: What if I were King?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: It's your game, Geoff. You play it.

dialogues.speaker: O 44-45 CUT
dialogues.text: (As GEOFFREY leans forward to speak, cut to -)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (JOHN in his bedroom. “He sits hunched up on the end of his bed, drinking from a bottle. The sound of a door opening. He looks up, glaring. (Cut to GEOFFREY briskly entering the room. As GEOFFREY hurries toward him, JOHN says --)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where are you when I need you?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (Hurrying up to him) You're angry. Good. Now, here's my plan.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm ruined. I've lost everything.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: We've got to make a deal with Philip.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 46 43 Continued

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We do? (GEOFFREY nods) Why?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Because you're out and Richard's in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What kind of deal?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: A war. If we three join and fight now we can finish Richa off.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You mean destroy him? (GEOFFREY nods) And Mother, too?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: And Mother too. Well, do we do it? Is it on?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I've got to think.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: You haven't time. We're extra princes now. You know where extra princes go?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Close up as his peril dawns on him) Down? (Cut from JOHN'S stricken face to - (PHILIP seated, as before, at the chess table)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Well? Does John want a war or doesn't he? (We pull back as GEOFFREY steps forward, protecting

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Do you? If John asks for your soldiers, will he get them?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: If John wants a war, he's got one.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: John, you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm still thinking.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Let me help. It's either Richard on the throne or you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (To PHILIP) you think we'd win?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I know it. (JOHN looks at GEOFFREY, then back to PHILIP, takes a deep breath and resolutely extends his hand. As GEOFFREY & PHILIP formally reach out for a three- way handshake, cut to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (HENRY in the Great Hall. The pantomime is still going on. HENRY rises, briskly starts to go)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY striding down a corridor. Far behind him, we see ALAIS, half-running, trying to catch up. Cut to -)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The door to the Parlor, from inside the room. It opens and HENRY strides in, ALAIS at his heels)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: But Henry -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Striding straight across to his desk) I'd appreciate a little quiet confidence. I have enough n picked at.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: But you've promised me to Richard.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Good God, you don't think I meant it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: (Not a bit relieved. If anything, even angrier) So that whole scene, all you said to John -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: en pe —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You think I'd ever give him up? When I've mothered him an fathered him and babied him? He's all I've got. How often you people have to hear it? Every supper? Should we start soup with who we love and who we don't?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I think you like it, passing me from hand to hand. What a to you, a collection plate? Or am I all you've got, like

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (He gets up, starts wandering about the room. The Christmas decorating and tree completed. Assorted packages the tree. A merry fire burns It couldn't be more Christmas trimming has been are arranged under in the fireplace. Eve) I've got to get the Aquitaine for John.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I talk people and you answer back in provinces.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What's the Aquitaine to Eleanor? It's not That's why she's outside She'll squeeze it out They get mixed up. a province, it's a way to torture me. wooing Richard, wheezing on the coals. of him. God but I'd love to eavesdrop. (Doing a creditable imitation of ELEANOR) I taught you prancing, lamb, and lute and flute - (Cut to the doorway. ELEANOR is there, a great pile of Christmas presents in her arms. She can barely see over the top. She laughs delightedly as she weaves into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's absolutely me. That's marvelous. (HENRY goes to her, takes some of the packages) I thought as long as I was coming down I'd bring them. (They move to the Christmas tree)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Whatever are you giving me?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're such a child. You always ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Reading from a package) To Henry. (He picks it up, weighs it) Heavy. (Delighted) It's my headstone. Eleanor, you spoil me.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I never could deny you anything. (She sits at the base of the tree, starts arranging the boxes just so. Across the room, ALAIS starts to leave)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Don't go. It nettles her to see how much I need you.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You need me, Henry, like a tailor needs a tinker's dam. (Cut from ALAIS to HENRY'S face. He is fond of the girl. Cut back to - (ALAIS in the doorway)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I know that look. He's going to say he loves me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Voice over) Like my life. (She is leaving as we cut to - (HENRY as he joins ELEANOR on the floor by the tree) HENRY (Cont) . I talk like that to keep her spirits up. Well, how'd you with Richard? Did you break his heart?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You think he ought to give me back the Aquitaine?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can't think why he shouldn't. After all, I've promised the throne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: The boy keeps wondering if your promises are any good.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There's no sense asking if the air's good when there's no else to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Exactly what I told him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Have you got it? Will he give it back? (All lightness and movement stop. The cards are down. They remain locked for a moment. Then -)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No Aquitaine for John.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've got to give him something. Isn't some agreement poss (She breaks the pose, rises to her feet. On top of the situation, enjoying herself)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Love, in a world where carpenters get resurrected, anythi possible. (HENRY, angry, trying to suppress it, rises, dusts off. There is, as in all rooms, straw on the floor)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You bore him, dammit: he's your son.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, heavens yes. Two hundred eighty days I bore him. I re it all. You'd only just found Rosamund.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why her so damn particularly? I've found other women.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Countless others.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What's your count? Let's have a tally of the bedspreads y spread out on. (Cut to ELEANOR in close up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 47 Continued O ELEANOR i Thomas Becket's. i (Cut to HENRY in close up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That's a lie! (Cut to ELEANOR, in close up)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut from ELEANOR, delighted, to HENRY furious and back to ELEANOR. Amused and musing - )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still care what I do.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (In an outburst of rage) I want the Aquitaine for John! I want it and I'll have it

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Is that menace you're conveying? Is it to be torture? Wil S you boil me or stretch me, which? Or am I to be perfora (HENRY storms to the desk, grabs a pile of papers)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I have the-documents and you will sign.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How can you force me to? Threats? Sign or I refuse to fee your Tears? Oh, sign before my heart goes crack. Bribes, offers, deals. (They are on opposite sides of the desk, leaning across it toward each other) I'm like the earth, old man; there isn't any way around m

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I adore you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Save your aching arches. That road's closed. | (They exchange looks. HENRY breaks it by sitting i at his desk, leaning back, very much at ease)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've got an offer for you, ma jolie.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: A deal, a deal. I give the richest province on the Contin to John for what. You tell me, mastermind. For what. (HENRY, close up. Relishing it)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Your freedom. (ELEANOR close up. She has just received a terrible blow)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh. (HENRY moves around the desk to her as he says)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Once Johnny has the Aquitaine, you're free. I'll let you Think on the loose in London, winters in Provence, improm trips to visit Richard anywhere he's killing people. All for a signature.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're good. (She backs away as he nears her, stopping with her to a charming creche lit by flickering candles)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I thought it might appeal to you. You always fancied traveling.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yes, I did. I even made poor Louis take me on Crusade. Ho that for blasphemy? I dressed my maids as Amazons and rod bare-breasted half way to Damascus. Louis had a seizure a damn near died of sun burn but the troops were dazzled. H I'm against the wall. (Cut to HENRY'S face. There is no pleasure on it. (Cut back to ELEANOR) To be a prisoner, to be bricked in when you've known the -- I'll never know how I've survived. These ten years, He have been unimaginable. And now you offer me the only thi want if I give up the only thing I treasure.

dialogues.speaker: AT
dialogues.text: 50 Continued (HENRY, sensing victory, picks the papers up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Sign them and we'll break the happy news. The Queen is fr John gets the Aquitaine and Richard marries Alais. (We look from face to face. Will she give in or won't she?)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yes. Let's have it done. I'll sign. (Delight floods HENRY'S face. He bends over the desk fiddling with the papers as ELEANOR moves to the desk chair and sits) ELEANOR (Cont) On one condition.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Name it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Have the wedding now. (Cut to HENRY, absolutely flummoxed. Then back to

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Why, I've surprised you. Surely it's not sudden. They've going down the aisle for sixteen years and that's a long John can be the best man -- that's a laugh -~ and you can the bride away. I'd love to watch you do it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Alais -- I can live without her.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And I thought you loved her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So I do.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Thank God. You frightened me: I was afraid this wouldn't (HENRY wheels on her, livid. He is like a great cat, wanting to pounce, ready to explode into violence. She looks at him with vast and calculated indifference and casually says - ) I wonder, do you ever wonder if I slept with Geoffrey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i j  47 iti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 oO 51 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: With my father?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's not true but one hears rumors. Don't you ever wonder (Cut back and forth between them on each succeeding line. One of them is going to explode)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
