dialogues.text: Is it rich, despising me? Is it rewarding?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No -- it's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Then stop it!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How? It's what I live for!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Exploding, hurling it at her) Rosamund, I loved you! (ELEANOR'S reaction is triumph. HE is ready to strike her. Instead, he storms toward the door, roaring - ) I'll show you. By Christ, I will. I'1l do it. (He throws open the door, bellows into the hallway) Where's a priest? Somebody dig me up a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SERVANTS are standing formally in the hallway. WILLIAM MARSHAL is among them. He hurries forward to HENRY) You. Bring me a bishop. (ELEANOR appears in the doorway behind HENRY. She addresses MARSHAL)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Get old Durham. He's just down the hall. (As MARSHAL bows, turns to go) Ask him to meet us in the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 49/ 51 52 52 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Roaring) John! Richard! Geoffrey! (He storms off down the hall. ELEANOR follows serenely after. SERVANTS scatter, running off to find the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We see quick cuts of SERVANTS running. Then brief shots of JOHN, PHILIP, GEOFFREY, RICHARD & ALAIS as each turns sharply, startled. Then short glimpses of each of them racing along, tearing upstairs, downstairs, through halls and corridors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the central hallway. HENRY is pacing, fidgeting and fuming. ELEANOR, calm and composed, stands, watching him. HENRY turns abruptly as - (One by one, RICHARD, JOHN, GEOFFREY, PHILIP & ALAIS come hurrying into the hall through various doors. (JOHN reaches HENRY first. As he pulls up in front of his father, breathless, skidding toa stop - )

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What's wrong? What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Richard's getting married. (The camera moves across all faces as they absorb the startling news)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Now? He's getting married now?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I never cease to marvel at the quickness of your mind.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You can't hurt me, you bag of bile, no matter what you sa (Moving to HENRY, supplicating) But you can. Father, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 53 53 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Because I say so. (MARSHAL slips in through the large door)

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: My lord, the bishop's waiting in the Chapel. (HENRY dismisses him with a brusque gesture)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Good. Let's get this over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He strides forward, throws open a door that gives into a corridor. (In the hall, a formal procession has been formed. ELEANOR has ALAIS by the hand and is leading her to

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You'll make a lovely bride. I wonder if I'll cry.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You sound as if you think it's going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And I do. (Everyone is in position. The group starts forward through the door and down the corridor)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: He's only plotting. Can't you tell when Henry's plotting?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Not this time.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: He'll never give me up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You think I won't?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Because you told me so.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're not my Helen. I won't fight a war to save a face. We're done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Co

dialogues.speaker: 53X1
dialogues.text: 54 54 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Wait ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (They reach the Great Hall door. HENRY throws it open. (Cut to inside the Hall as they enter.)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: (As they surge past the camera) You don't want me, Richard. Honestly, you don't. We're no right for each other. Our marriage wouldn't work. We're n in love, we'd never be happy ... (From high above, we zoom in on the chapel door. They stand before it) Not yet. -Oh, please not yet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. CHAPEL
dialogues.text: (HENRY mounts the steps, throws open the chapel door. the chapel is exquisite, intimate. Candles burn, shedding soft warm light. The BISHOP OF DURHAM, an aged, sweet-faced man, stands waiting on the altar in the distance. (As the procession moves into the foyer of the chapel, ALAIS breaks rank, draws back. To HENRY as he moves brusquely to her) I won't do.it. I won't say the words, not one of them. (HENRY all but drags her back toward the procession, casting an embarrassed-father look to DURHAM on the altar. (Cut to DURHAM who smiles back with paternal understanding. (Cut to ALAIS as HENRY positions her in the procession) ALAIS (Cont) Henry, please. It makes no sense. Why give me up? What do you get? What are you gaining?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (With vast innocence as, rather like a bridal consultant, he checks over the bridal party) Why, the Aquitaine, of course. (We take in their faces. JOHN'S puzzlement, GEOFFREY'S amusement, ELEANOR'S dismay, RICHARD'S dawning rage. RICHARD moves up the steps to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What's that again?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Your mother gets her freedom and I get the Aquitaine. (To ELEANOR) This is the proposition, isn't it? You did agree.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Of course she did, I knew, I knew it. It was all pretense And I believed you. I believed it all.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I meant it all.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No wedding. There will be no wedding. (HENRY throws DURHAM a look of excruciating parental embarrassment as he draws RICHARD aside and whispers)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But, my boy. Look -- Durham's waiting. (Cut to DURHAM beginning to look a bit puzzled by it all. (Cut back to RICHARD & HENRY. RICHARD'S face is set and stony) You've simply got to marry her. It isn't much to ask. For sake, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (So embarrassed and upset) But I've promised Philip. Think of my position.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Damn the wedding and to hell with your position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 56 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You don't dare defy me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don't I? (HENRY throws a glance of badly-rattled desperation in DURHAM'S direction, then beckons PHILIP forward)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're the King of France, for goodness sake. Speak up. D something. (RICHARD strides forward as PHILIP approaches)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Make a threat, why don't you. Scare me.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Dunce.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Am I?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: He never meant to have the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: You're good at rage. I like the way you play it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Boy, don't ever call a King a liar to his face.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I'm not a boy -- to you or anybody.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Boy, you came here asking for a wedding or the vexin back By God, you don't get either one. It's no to both. She ne marries, not while I'm alive.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Your life and never are two different times.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Not on my clock, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 Continued (PHILIP, stiff with anger, turns and strides out of the Chapel. ALAIS, weak with relief, leans against the door frame. HENRY is just turning to her when - )

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Listen to the lion. Flash a yellow tooth and frighten me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Don't spoil it, Richard. Take it like a good sport.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How's your bad leg and your back and all the rest of it. You're getting old. One day you'll have me once too often

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: When? I'm fifty now. My God, boy, I'm the oldest man I kn I've got a decade on the Pope. What's it to be? The broad sword when I'm eighty-five?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I'm not a second son. Not now. Your Henry's in the vault, know.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I know. I've seen him there.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I'll have the crown.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You'll have what Daddy gives you. }

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I am next in line. i i HENRY i To nothing. i

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Then we'll have the broadswords now.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: This minute?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: On the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So we're at war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes, we're at war. I have two thousand men at Poitiers.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Can they hear you? Call and see who comes. You are as clo to Poitiers as you're going to get.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You don't dare hold me prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Until we've all agreed that John comes next, I can and wi (RICHARD starts to stalk away) You are a king's son so I treat you with respect. You hav freedom of the castle.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (With great bravura as he goes) The castle doesn't stand that holds me. Post your guards. (ELEANOR, ALAIS, HENRY, GEOFFREY & JOHN stand watching him go. Cut to - (JOHN, close up, as the miracle dawns)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: My God, I'm king again. Fantastic. It's a miracle. (He turns to GEOFFREY) Are you happy for me, Geoff?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: I'm happy for us both. (GEOFFREY throws a loving arm around JOHN'S shoulders as they start out, past ELEANOR. We stay with ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I came close, didn't I. (She turns to ALAIS who stands near her) I almost had my freedom and I almost had you for my son. I should have liked it, being free. (She turns to HENRY. Cut to him. Seated comfortably in a pew, he gives an apologetic shrug-and-sigh to DURHAM) (Cut to DURHAM who, both bewildered and pleased to be dismissed, starts to leave the altar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 Continued (CUT back to ELEANOR) You played it nicely. You were good.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Cut to Henry stretching, luxuriating, loving it) I really was. I fooled you, didn't I. God, but I do love being King. (Cut to ELEANOR, alone)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well, Henry, Hege and lord, what happens now? (Cut to HENRY as he rises, moves toward her)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've no idea. I know I'm winning and I know I'1l win but the next move is ... : (He is shrugging as ALAIS moves into the picture)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I was so scared -- You mustn't play with feelings, Henry. with mine.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Cupping her face in his hands) It wasn't possible to lose you. I must hold you dearer th thought. (cut to ELEANOR. In the doorway, she stops and turns)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: One thing.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Voice over) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: May I watch you kiss her? (Cut from her, close up, to HENRY close up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Can't you ever stop? (Cut to ELEANOR, close up)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I watch you every night. I conjure it before I sleep.

dialogues.speaker: OO
dialogues.text: 54 55 60 Continued (HENRY, close up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Leave it at that. (ELEANOR close up)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: My curiosity is intellectual. I want to see how accurate (We see the three of them as HENRY opens his arms to ALAIS who stands close to him. ELEANOR is in the background, framed in the doorway)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Forget the dragon in the doorway: come. (ALAIS moves into his arms) Believe I love you, for I do. Believe I'm yours forever, am. Believe in my contentment and the joy you give me and believe -- (HENRY close up as he breaks, turns toward ELEANOR) You want more? (Cut to ELEANOR, close up, eyes burning at him. (Cut to HENRY, staring back at her. Then he turns to ALAIS and we see the three of them again) HENRY (Cont) I'm an old man in an empty place. Be with me. (She raises her lips to his. They kiss tenderly at first, then passionately. The camera moves across their faces, ELEANOR always in the background. (The sound of caroling grows louder as we begin moving closer to ELEANOR'S face. She watches and she waits. The picture slowly faced to black as the camera moves from her face and out and up into cloudless, magnificent sky.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (From black, we come up with a jolt on RICHARD. Sword in his hand, he is racing crouched and silent across a shadowed empty section of courtyard. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In the best Erroll Flynn tradition, he effort- lessly vaults one low wall, then another. Then, without pausing, he gathers himself and vaults a final barricade. (Cut to RICHARD from below. The final barricade is a good twenty feet above us. We see RICHARD sailing down. (Cut to RICHARD, landing cat-like on his feet. He looks up. (Cut to TWO SOLDIERS, swords drawn, standing at the ready. From a distance, we hear a high pitched deliriously happy giggle. (Cut to RICHARD. He looks up.) (Cut to JOHN, high on the top of a wall, looking down. He waves a friendly wave.) (Cut to RICHARD glaring up at him with loathing. (Cut to a stout vine growing up a castle wall. Hands appear at the bottom of the picture. Swiftly, RICHARD appears, making his apparently effortless way up the sheer wall. RICHARD pauses a moment, looks down. (Cut to the ground from RICHARD'S POV. It is a long way down. (Cut to the top of the wall. It is a long way up. (Cut to RICHARD climbing again. Almost at once, he reaches the top of the wall, swings himself up. He looks about. The camera draws back to show him high on the. top of the towering Gate House that guards the entrance to the castle yard. (He moves to the front edge of the tower roof. There are vines on the outside. He looks further. Still none. Seemingly hesitating, he moves fearlessly over the edge. Hands and feet finding tiny crevasses in the rough-hewn stone, he starts down. (Cut to RICHARD further down the wall. He looks up. (Cut to the top of the tower from RICHARD'S POV. He has come a long way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 58 Continued O (Cut to RICHARD looking down. He looks away, is about to start climbing again, frowns, looks down a second time.) 59 (Cut to the base of the tower from RICHARD'S POV. It's a long drop. Something moves in the shadows. (Zoom down to JOHN & SEVERAL SOLDIERS, swords drawn standing on the drawbridge looking up at RICHARD. JOHN, hand over his mouth, is trying not to giggle. The urge is too great. Peals of delighted laughter burst out of him.) 60 (Cut to RICHARD, white with rage. He takes the dagger from his belt, takes careful aim and throws it.) 61 (Cut to JOHN, laughter dying in his throat. He is looking down at the wooden bridge near his feet. (Cut to RICHARD'S dagger, quivering in the bridge, no more than three feet away) 62 (Cut to RICHARD as he leaps the last ten feet of = the wall landing lightly near JOHN. He moves to OQ his dagger, picks it up. He moves to JOHN, gives him a look of pure hatred and stalks on past him back into the castle yard.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to a TREASURE CHEST piled high with jewels: bracelets, necklaces, huge rings, strands of pearls, a magnificent crown. (A hand appears. The hand has rings on every finger. It rummages among the jewels, finally selecting an enormous heavily bejeweled bib necklace. The camera draws back to reveal -- (ELEANOR. She is seated at a table in her room, alone. She has been putting on jewelry for quite some time, and bracelets; necklaces; she is covered with the stuff. Her face looks ravaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: } (As she puts the necklace on, she says - )

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How beautiful you make me. What might Solomon have sung h seen this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 Continued (There is a mirror on the table. She starts to pick it up, then stops) ELEANOR (Cont) I can't. I'd turn to salt. (Mask slipping for a moment) I've lost again. I'm done for now. (Finding the mask again) Well, there'll be other Christmases. (She takes an extremely elaborate necklace from the chest. Addressing it) I'd hang you from the nipples but you'd shock the childre (She puts it on. For a moment, her pain shows clearly) They kissed sweetly, didn't they. (Hardening again as she leans over the jewel chest) I'll have him next time. I can wait. Ah - there you are: (Cut to the crown in the chest. Voice over) My comfort and my company. (Her hands appear. She picks the crown up) We're locked in for another year: four seasons more. Oh, desolation, what a life's work. (GEOFFREY appears in the doorway some distance behind her. She turns, smiling brightly as she puts the crown on. She already wears a small coronet and the effect of two crowns on at once is a little: mad) Is it too much? Be sure to squint as you approach. You ma awed by my beauty

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Is that why you'[re here -- to tell me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ce 64 63 Continued

dialogues.speaker: O GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: I thought you might be lonely. (ELEANOR removes the crown, holds it out to him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Here, Chancellor. Try it on for size.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: It's puzzling. I remember my third birthday. Not just pictures of the garden or the gifts but who did what to w and how it felt. My memory stretches back that far and ne once can I remember anything from you or father warmer th indifference. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I don't know. (He is by the table, looking down at her. They are close)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'm weary and you want a simple answer and I haven't one. (Starting to remove the jewelry) Z I was thinking earlier of Peter Abelard. I was a Queen oS fifteen in those days and on dull afternoons I'd go wa Eloise watch Abelard spread heresy like bonemeal in the p gardens. Here the Seine and there the cypress trees and h bored me. Thought, pure thought, flashed clear as water a around me and all I could think about was how to make a C of a monkish husband. I'd like to hear the old man talk a I'd listen now. For my ambition's thin with age and all t mysteries are as plump as ever. (Looking up at GEOFFREY) I read minds. In yours, a shapely hand is writing, "Cleve Mother, what's your clever reason for this clever talk?" isn't clever but you'll make it so. (She reaches up, gently touches his cheek) I am so sick of all of you. (Cut to JOHN who pops jauntily into the room)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I thought I'd come and gloat a little. (Cut to all three as ELEANOR starts removing jewelry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Mother's tired. Come stick pins tomorrow morning. I'll be more responsive then.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It's no fun goading anyone tonight. (RICHARD storms into the room)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The bastard's boxed us up. (Cut to ELEANOR, utterly unconcerned, removing jewels)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What's that, dear? (RICHARD strides into the picture)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We're his prisoners if that interests you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Why should it? I'm his prisoner anyway.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It was -~ correct me if I'm wrong, but it was my impressi that you wanted Henry's throne for me.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: We've lost it this time, Richard. We can't win.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You think I'm finished, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: So I do. I've suffered more defeats than you have teeth. I know if and when it happens.to me. Take your wormwood l a good boy. Do it and go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I will be king.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And so you will. But not this year. Oh, leave it, Richard Let it go for now.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I can't. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: es

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 66 Continued (Cut to JOHN across the room)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It's not so hard. Try saying after me. John wins, I lose. (RICHARD starts across the room to JOHN)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What if John died? (Cut to JOHN, registering instant panic)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You wouldn't dare.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (Moving into the picture) Why on earth wouldn't I? (RICHARD'S hand moves to his dagger. JOHN races across the room to the protection of his mother. She rises, looks balefully toward RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: He has a knife. He always has a knife. We all have knives This is eighty-three and we're barbarians. (Her eyes rake across her children. We cut to them. Voice over) ELEANOR (Cont) How clear we make it. Oh, my piglets, we're the origins o war. (Cut back to ELEANOR, looking at them) Not history's forces nor the times nor justice nor the la it nor causes nor religions nor ideas nor kinds of govern nor any other thing. (Cut to ELEANOR close to RICHARD) We are the killers; we breed war. (Moving on to JOHN) We carry it, like syphilis, inside. (Moving on to GEOFFREY) Dead bodies rot in field and stream because the living on rotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 Continued (We see them all as she draws them close together) For the love of God, can't we love one another just a lit that's how peace begins. We have so much to love each oth for. We have such possibilities, my children. We could ch the world. (They want to be loved. She wants to love them. As she starts to reach out for RICHARD, GEOFFREY says - )

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: And while we hugged each other, what would Philip do? (Cut to JOHN in total dismay)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, good God, Philip. We're supposed to start a war. If Father finds out, I'll be ruined. (JOHN starts for the door. GEOFFREY joins him)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Steady, John; don't panic.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Some adviser you are. (JOHN hurries £rom the room as GEOFFREY says - )

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Don't do anything without me. Let me handle it. (Cut to ELEANOR, RICHARD beside her. She is alive again)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: He's made a pact with Philip. (To GEOFFREY as he joins them) You advised John into making war. That peerless boy! He's disinherited himself. When Henry finds out, when I tell h what John's done -- I need a little time. Can you keep Jo away from Philip 'til I say so?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Anything you say. (He kisses her hand and bounds from the room as she turns to RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I want you out of here before this breaks. And that needs Philip. Go to him. Be desperate, promise anything: the ve Brittany. Then once you're free and John is out of favor, we'll make further plans.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You talk to Philip. You're the diplomat; you see him.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're a friend. you know him; I don't. (RICHARD looks at her expressionlessly, then starts to the door) And Richard. (He steps in the doorway) Promise anything. (Cut to RICHARD close up. He either loves his Mum or loathes her. This is loathing. As he turns and goes - (Cut to ELEANOR alone in the center of the room, as far from her as possible. As she turns round full circle - ) ELEANOR (Cont) I haven't lost. It isn't over. Oh, I've got the old man t time. The damn fool thinks he loves John. He believes it. That's where the Kris goes in. (Cut to her close up, all triumph gone) Knives, knives ... it was a fine thought, wasn't it. Oh, Henry, done a big thing badly. (She starts to look for something. We follow her gaze about the room. Voice over) Where's that mirror? I am Eleanor and I can look at anyth (The camera finds the mirror. Her hand appears, picks the mirror up. We see her reflection, wavy and distorted in the primitive glass) My, what a lovely girl. (The camera moves from the reflection to her face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We move across the is quiet here. The 69 agonized face to HENRY'S. He of infinite tenderness. He is a large chair in the Parlor. is a great sense of warmth and they start slowly from the the corridor as they pass the the floor, arms flung, for It is a clear, cold night. the MEN are bundled up and 63 Continued © ELEANOR (Cont) How could her king have left ner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut from ELEANOR'S wears an expression gazing down at ALAIS who lies drowsing in his arms. They are sitting in Candles glow; there peace.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Off to bed? (ALAIS nods, smiles, opens her eyes. She gets up and we see her for a moment filled, like a child, with happiness, staring at the Christmas tree. HENRY joins her and room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We pick them up in - Great Hall. We have them, moving into and through 7) the hall. The party is dying but not dead. A few NOBLES are drunk on warmth, around sleeping dogs. Of the others, some drink, some sing softly, some are in amorous circumstances with male and female SERVANTS.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (We move through the great hall, out the door and into the Courtyard. The moon is bright and there are endless stars. The yard itself seems to glow with dozens of tiny campfires. Most of asleep. A few sit huddled by the fires. There is faint caroling, soft and sweet.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: yard and into the Kitchen. All KITCHEN STAFF, exhausted and filthy, lie asleep on the floor. The floor is littered with animals alive and dead, entrails, excrement. Tomorrow's meat new slaughtered, hangs still dripping from huge hearth glows. great hooks. The fire in the We move into the fire.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (When we pull back, away from the coals, it is from : the fire in Henry's bedroom. The door is just L opening. ALAIS steps through. Behind her, HENRY i hesitates, frowning in thought.) i

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Henry?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Wait up for me. I won't be long. (He closes the door. (Cut to another door. A hand appears, taps lightly on it and we hear - )

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (Whispering, voice over) Philip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to PHILIP inside his bedroom. The room is more luxuriously furnished than the others in the castle, PHILIP having brought his own refinements with him. There is a canope bed, wine glasses and decanter sit on a table. (PHILIP preparing for bed, wears a dressing gown. He is turning sharply when we see him. Cut to - )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (GEOFFREY in the hallway as he taps again. PHILIP opens the door. GEOFFREY slips in, closes it behind him. He is keyed high; quiet, tense, excited)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: It's working out. By morning I can be the chosen son. the crown can come to me. Are you still with me? (PHILIP nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to fight them ali. They'll bank together once happens. Have I got your word? f

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Do I have yours? All England's land in France if I suppor you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued (GEOFFREY nods. PHILIP looks at him speculatively)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Are we allies, then?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: (Warmly taking his hand) We were born to be.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: I should say something solemn but I haven't time. (Half way to the door) I'm off to Father with the news that John's a traitor. Af that -- (Cut to JOHN as, livid, he charges out from behind a tapestry)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You stink, you know that? You're a stinker and you stink. (Cut to GEOFFREY. He doesn't bat an eye)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Come along. We're finished here. (Cut to JOHN, looking wildly about the room)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'll kill you. Where's a dagger? (He can't find anything. Then, seeing a lethal-looking massive candlestick, he grabs it, raises it high over his head and charges at GEOFFREY. (GEOFFREY crouches slightly as JOHN comes tearing at him. At the last moment, GEOFFREY sidesteps gracefully, tripping JOHN as he hurtles by. (JOHN sprawls out painfully on the floor. GEOFFREY glares at him, anger and derision on his face)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Dumb. If you're a prince, there's hope for every ape in Africa. (He goes to one knee beside JOHN as JOHN sits up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued I had you saved. I wasn't on my way to Father but he was. would have gone to Henry and betrayed you. Look: it's in face. (JOHN looks up. Cut to PHILIP, then back to JOHN)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Convinced and dismayed) It's true. I don't know who my friends are. (There is a tapping at the door. PHILIP & GEOFFREY exchange a quick glance.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to RICHARD in the corridor. He darts a look one way, then the other. Satisfied he's still alone, he raps again and whispers - )

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: ’ Philip. (Cut back to GEOFFREY as he bounds to his feet and indicating the tapestry where JOHN was hidden, asks - )

dialogues.speaker: ' GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: May we?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: That's what tapestries are for. (PHILIP starts toward the door. GEOFFREY tugs JOHN to his feet, bustles him toward the tapestry)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I've ruined everything. I'1l never learn. (JOHN & GEOFFREY duck behind the tapestry) (Cut to PHILIP standing by the door)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Is someone there? I heard my name. (He opens the door. RICHARD stands in the doorway)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I called it.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Richard. Hello, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67X1 Continued

dialogues.speaker: O RICHARD
dialogues.text: You're half way to bed. I'll wait for morning. PHILIP t Come in. (He moves into the room. We stay with RICHARD in the doorway)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Mother sent me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to PHILIP standing by the table and wine decanter)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Come in anyway. (He picks up the decanter, pours. RICHARD moves into the picture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our alchemists have stumbled on the art of boiling burgun It turns to steam and when it cools, we call it brandywin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O I'm Henry's prisoner. (PHILIP smiles) You find that charming?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Then why the charming smile?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I thought, I can't think why, of when you were in Paris l Can it be two whole years ago?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It can. I need an army, Philip. (PHILIP hands him a glass)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: It will take the cold away.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: é I must have soldiers. 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67X1 Continued (PHILIP strolls away, moving casually about the room)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Have I aged? Do I seem older to you? They've been two fie years. I've studied and I've trained to be a king. (Cut to RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I'll have your answer -- yes or no. (Cut to PHILIP as he spins sharply toward RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: You'll have it when I give it. (Charming again, he moves across the room to

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You see? I've changed. I'm not the boy you taught to hunt years ago. Remember? Racing after boar, you flying first; scrambling after, all day into dusk -- (RICHARD turns abruptly away from him, starts to go) Don't go.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I must know: will you help me? (PHILIP sits in one of the chairs by the table)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Sit and we'll discuss it. (RICHARD moves to the other chair and sits stiffly) You never write.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: To anyone.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Why should I make you King of England? Aren't I better of with John or Geoffrey? Why have you to fight when I could the cretin or the fiend? (Cut to behind the tapestry. JOHN indignant, GEOFFREY amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67X1 Continued (Cut to RICHARD & PHILIP) RICHARD j Would we fight?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: We're fighting now. Good night. (He starts to rise, the interview terminated)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You're still a boy.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: In some ways. Which way did you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You haven't asked how much my help is worth.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: You'll tell me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You can have the vexin back.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: And what else?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: All of Brittany. (Cut to behind the tapestry. GEOFFREY angry now and JOHN amused) (Cut back to RICHARD & PHILIP)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: That's Geoffrey's.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Does that matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly to Geoffrey. And what else? i

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That's all your help is worth. i PHILIP And in return, what do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 67X1 Continued (With each succeeding line, we cut back and forth in close up from RICHARD'S face to PHILIP'S)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Two thousand soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: And what else?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Five hundred knights on horse.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: And what else?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Arms and siege equipment.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: And what else?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I never wrote because I thought you'd never answer. (Pull back to show them both. PHILIP is expressionless)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You got married.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Does that make a difference?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I've spent two years on every street in hell.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That's odd. I didn't see you there. (PHILIP rises, eyes on RICHARD. Then RICHARD stands. Slowly, PHILIP extends his hand. RICHARD takes it. PHILIP turns and, in measured step, starts moving toward the bed. RICHARD, still holding his hand, follows. (Cut to the interior of the bed. PHILIP'S hand comes through the curtains, draws them back. We see them through the opening)

dialogues.speaker: 67X2
dialogues.text: 77 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You haven't said you loved me.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: When the times comes. (There is a tapping at the door. PHILIP & RICHARD, paralyzed, exchanged startled glances.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY in the corridor. He glances about. Then raps again and whispers - )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Philip. (Cut back to PHILIP & RICHARD at the bed. RICHARD is in great confusion. PHILIP is thinking hard. (Cut to behind the tapestry. JOHN, frightened, turns to GEOFFREY. GEOFFREY, alive with excitement, puts a finger on JOHN'S lips. (Cut to PHILIP as he puts a finger to RICHARD'S lips, helps him into the bed. PHILIP draws the curtains shut. (Cut to PHILIP crossing toward the door. (Cut to HENRY outside in the hall)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Philip, lad. (The door opens. From HENRY'S POV) It's not too late at night?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I'd hoped you'd come.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (We see the room from HENRY'S POV as he enters) Good; we can't leave negotiations where they are. (Turning to PHILIP who moves to the table and pours from the decanter) I keep looking for your father in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78 67X2 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: He's not there. (We see them both as HENRY settles in RICHARD'S chair.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I miss him. Has Richard or the Queen been here to see you

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Does it matter? If they haven't yet, they will.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I want to reach a settlement. I left you with too little earlier. (PHILIP hands HENRY a glass, sits in the other chair)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Yes; nothing is too little.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you're not fonder of me, lad. Your father alway said "Be fond of stronger men."

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: No wonder he loved everyone.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've come to you to offer peace.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Piss on your peace.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Your father would have wept.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: My father was a weeper.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Fight me and you'll lose.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I can't lose, Henry. I have time. Just look at you. (Cut to HENRY, then back to PHILIP) Great heavy arms -- they'd crush me like a leaf of lettuc But each year they get a little heavier. The sand goes pi in the glass. I'm in no hurry, Henry. I've got time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 67X2 Continued (Cut to HENRY as he rises, angry)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Suppose I hurry things along? What if I say that England war with France? (Cut to PHILIP calmly looking up at HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Then France surrenders. I don't have to fight to win. Tak all you want -- this county, that one. You won't keep it (Cut to HENRY, scornful)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What kind of courage have you got? (Cut to PHILIP, cool and unperturbed)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: The tidal kind: it comes and goes. (Cut to HENRY as he breaks out into a delighted smile and sits again. We see them both)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: By God, I'd love to turn you loose on Eleanor. (The decanter in his hand) More brandywine?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: You recognize it?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Filling his glass) They were boiling it in Ireland before the snakes left. (sitting back, settling in his chair) Well -- things look a little bleak for Henry, don't they. You'll say yes to Richard when he comes; arms, soldiers, anything he asks for.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I'd be foolish not to.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: And withdraw it all before the battle ever started.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you, in my place?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why fight Henry when his sons will do it for you.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 67X2 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Yes, exactly.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You've got promise, lad. That's first class thinking. (He raises his glass and drinks. (Cut to RICHARD in the bed, angry and betrayed. (Cut to behind the tapestry. More anger and ‘betrayal. (Cut to PHILIP & HENRY as HENRY puts his glass down ) Good night. (HENRY rises. PHILIP looks up, uncertain for the first time)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Good night? you're going? (HENRY nods benignly) But we haven't settled anything.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We open Christmas packages at noon. 'Til then. (HENRY starts to go. Cut to PHILIP, rising)

dialogues.speaker: _ PHILIP
dialogues.text: You can't be finished with me. (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I am. And it's been very satisfactory. (Cut to PHILIP)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: What's so satisfactory? (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Winning is. I did just win. Surely you noticed. (Cut to PHILIP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 67X2 Continued

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Not a thing. You haven't won a damn thing. (We see them both as HENRY moves Slowly to PHILIP saying - )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I found out the way your mind words and the kind of man y are. I know your plans and expectations. You have burbled every bit of what you've got. I know exactly what you wil and exactly what you are. And I've told you exactly nothi To these aged eyes, boy, that's what winning looks like. Dormez bien. (With which he turns and, as we follow him, moves toward the door)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: (Voice over) You -- (HENRY stops and turns. Cut to PHILIP) You made my father nothing. You were always better. You bullied him, you bellied with his wife, you beat him down every war, you twisted every treaty, you played mock-the and then you made him love you for it. (He begins stalking toward HENRY) I was there. His last words went to you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He was a loving man and you learned nothing of it.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: I learned how much fathers live in sons. A king like you policy prepared on everything. What's the official line o sodomy? How stands the crown on boys who do with boys? (Cut to RICHARD in the bed, disbelief, shock on his face. It can't be happening) (Cut to HENRY as he moves away from PHILIP)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Richard finds his way into so many legends. Let's hear yo and see how it compares. (As PHILIP speaks, he follows HENRY, pressing him)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: He found me first when I was fifteen. We were hunting. It after dark. My horse fell. I was thrown. I woke to Richar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 67X2 Continued touching me. He asked me if I loved him -- "Philip, do yo love me?" -- and I told him yes. (Cut to RICHARD in the bed. He is wracked with pain and rage. It is excruciating. (Cut to PHILIP & HENRY, close up) You know why I told him yes? So one day I could tell you about it. You cannot imagine what that "yes" cost. Or per you can. Imagine snuggling to a chancred whore and, bendi back your lips in something like a smile, saying: "Yes, I you and I find you beautiful." I don't know how I did it. Cut to the bed as RICHARD leaps through the curtains)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No -- it wasn't like that. (Cut to PHILIP, cold and cutting)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: But it was. (Cut to RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You loved me. (Cut to PHILIP)

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Never. (Cut to RICHARD as he turns to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Get out. Please! I don't want you here.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's no great joy to be here.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: So the royal corkscrew finds me twisted, does he?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'll go tell your mother: she'll be pleased. (He starts to go. RICHARD follows him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 67X2 Continued

dialogues.speaker: O RICHARD
dialogues.text: She knows. She sent me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Turning on RICHARD. They stand face to face) How completely hers you are.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You've had four sons. Who do you claim? Not Henry. Not my buried brother. Not that monument to muck, that epic idio Why him? Why always him and never me?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He was the oldest -- he came first.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Christ, Henry, is that all?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You went with Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You never called for me. You never said my name. I would walked or crawled. I'd have done anything. Oo (HENRY turns away, unable to face it)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's not my fault. I won't be blamed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I only wanted you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No -- it's my crown. You want my kingdom.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Keep your kingdom. (Cut to HENRY close up as he wheels toward RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That I will. (Cut to RICHARD, close up)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I hope it kills you. (Cut to HENRY, close up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67X2 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Thank God I have another son. Thank God for John. (Cut to the tapestry as GEOFFREY steps out from hiding)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Who shall we thank for Geoffrey? (Moving to HENRY) You don't think much of me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Much? I don't think of you at all.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Nurse used to say I had your hands. I might have more of Try seeing me. I haven't Richard's military skill but he here betraying you, not I. I haven't John's I don't know -- God knows what you can see in John -- and he's betraye too. (Cut to JOHN who, red with rage, peeps through a slit in the tapestry. (Cut to the room from JOHN'S POV)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You think I'd ever make you king?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: You'll make me king because I'm all you've got. (Pointing to RICHARD) I was to be his Chancellor. Ask him why.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Starting to leave the room) I've heard enough.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: For moving John to treason. (Cut to HENRY, close up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't doubt he offered, I don't doubt you tried and I d doubt John loves me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 67X2 Continued (Cut to GEOFFREY who steps to the tapestry)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Like a glutton loves his lunch. (He pulls the tapestry back, revealing JOHN. JOHN glares at GEOFFREY with pure loathing)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You turd. (Cut to the full room)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well, John?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It isn't what you think.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What do I think?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What Geoffrey said. I'd never plot against you, ever.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I know; you're a good boy. (JOHN, encouraged, moves toward HENRY. Just JOHN & HENRY now)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Can I go now, please? It's late. I ought to be in bed. (HENRY grabs JOHN by the shoulders, shakes him)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Couldn't you wait. Couldn't you trust me? It was all your Couldn't you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Will you listen to the grief.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Who do you think I built this kingdom for? (JOHN, in a rage, shakes himself loose)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Me? Daddy did it all for me? When can I have it, Daddy? until we bury you? Not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 67X2 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're just like them. And after all I've given you. (Cut to JOHN close up)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I got it. I know what you gave. (Cut to HENRY close up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I loved you. (Cut to JOHN close up)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You're a cold and bloody bastard, you are, and you don't anything. (Cut to HENRY. He is stunned, blank with shock) (Cut to GEOFFREY)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: I'm it, I'm all that's left. (Cut to HENRY and his three sons) GEOFFREY (Cont) Here, Father; here I am. (We move toward HENRY, closer and closer to his unseeing eyes)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: My life, when it is written, will read better than it liv Henry Fitz-Empress, first Plantagnet, a King at twenty-on ablest soldier of an able time. He led men well, he cared justice when he could and ruled, for thirty years, a stat great as Charlemagne's. He married out of love a woman ou legend. Not in Rome or Alexandria or Camelot has there be such a Queen. She bore him many children -- but no sons. Henry had no sons. (Cut to JOHN, RICHARD & GEOFFREY side by side. voice over) He had three whiskered things but he disowned them. You'r mine. We're not connected. I deny you. None of you will g any crown. (Cut to HENRY, close up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67X2 Continued HENRY (Cont) I leave you nothing and I wish you plague. May all your children breech and die. (He turns, moves to the doorway, stops and looks back.) (Cut to the room from HENRY'S POV) My boys are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY as he starts unsteadily down the corridor) I've lost my boys. (He stops, glares up toward the Deity) You dare to damn me, do you? Well, I damn you back. (Like a Biblical figure, shaking his fist at the sky) HENRY (Cont) God damn you. (Moving blindly down the corridor again) My boys are gone. I've lost my boys. Oh, Jesus, all my bo (We watch as his figure grows smaller and smaller.) (CUT to the bottom of a broad stone stairway, looking up. HENRY appears at the top, starts unseeingly down. We hear a sudden burst of raucous laughter as a drunken NOBLEMAN, his arm around a WENCH, moves abruptly into the picture. (THEY start, weaving, up the stairs. HENRY passes them, unseeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CUT to HENRY crossing the hall at the base of the stairs. A SERVANT, tidying up for the night, scurries past, pausing to bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CUT to the open doorway of the Great Hall, looking in from the corridor. The hall is empty save for a few NOBLES who lie sprawled in drunken sleep. SERVANTS move about, exhaustedly cleaning up the mess. HENRY, walking down the corridor, passes through the picture. The camera follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the Parlor. Candles, about to go out, are flickering on the Christmas tree. Masses of presents lie at the base of the tree. HENRY appears, walks unseeing through the room. A church bell starts to toll eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY'S bedroom. The tolling continues. ALAIS lies curled up, asleep on the bed where HENRY left her. A noise awakens her. She starts up, turning to the door. (Cut to the door from ALAIS'S POV. It opens. HENRY stands in the doorway. He starts into the room. (Cut to ALAIS, smiling, rubbing her eyes.)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: What time is it? (Something's wrong. Rising from the bed) Henry? (Cut to HENRY standing in front of the fire, staring blindly into it. ALAIS moves into the picture, stands beside him. (Cut to HENRY & ALAIS seen through the fire) What's happened, Henry? What's the matter? (He doesn't seem to hear her. He frowns at a passing thought, turns and starts away.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY at the door. He turns back, seems to see ALAIS for a moment, then turns away and moves out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 Continued

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 (Cut to a shadowy hallway. Eyes glowing in the dark -- dogs' eyes. HENRY moves into the picture, past the dogs. Far behind him, down the corridor, we can dimly make out ALAIS.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to an exterior door seen from outside. It opens. HENRY steps through, his face immobile, like a Greek mask. We follow him as he moves out into the freezing clear bright night, prowling along the battlements. Though he wears no robe or coat, he does not register the cold. (Cut to ALAIS shivering in the doorway, her face alive with love and compassion for her man. (Cut to HENRY from ALAIS'S POV. He is in the distance now, a small figure moving along the walls of a great castle. The castle looks like ivory in the moonlight. (Cut to a SOLDIER on Guard Duty. Heavily robed, he is nonetheless half frozen. He sees something, stiffens to attention. (Cut to HENRY moving along the battlements. We see him pass the shivering GUARD. (Cut to HENRY sitting, looking out over the same bit of wall from where he first caught sight of ELEANOR'S boat that morning. (Cut to the night from HENRY'S POV. We see ELEANOR'S boat anchored at the wharf. (Cut to HENRY looking at the boat. He shuts his eyes, unable to bear what he is thinking. He lies back, stretching out on the cold stone, and looks up at the sky. (The camera, following the rising mist of HENRY'S breath, turns up to the sky. It is cloudless, crammed with an infinity of stars.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to a tiny bed of gently glowing coals, very close up. As we see them, we hear - )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 Cont inued >

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: (Singing, voice over) The Christmas wine is in the pot, The Christmas coals are red. I'll spend my day the lover's way, Unwrapping all my gifts in bed. (As she sings, we pull slowly back. The coals are in a small copper brazier. On the brazier, we see a small pot. ALAIS'S hands appear. One holds a tiny spice jar; the other takes a pinch of spice and drops it in the pot. > (We continue back as we see ALAIS sitting on the floor by the brazier. Then we see HENRY'S bedroom beyond her and, at the last, ELEANOR standing in the doorway. She looks absolutely desolate) The Christmas goose is on the spit, The Christmas -- (She stops singing as she senses someone. She turns. (Cut to ELEANOR. We see her pull herself together. As if nothing in the world were wrong, she moves into the room saying - )

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No one else is caroling tonight: it might as well be Lent When I was little, Christmas was a time of great confusio me. The Holy Land had two kings, God and Uncle Raymond, a never knew whose birthday we were celebrating. (Reaching ALAIS, she looks fondly down at her)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Henry isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Good;.we can talk behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don't you know? ALAIS shakes her head. ELEANOR sits on the floor by her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 716 91 Continued There was a scene with beds and tapestries and many thing so - (She leans forward over the pot on the brazier) Spiced wine. I'd forgotten Henry liked it. May I stay?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: (She rises, puts the spice pot on a table) It's your room just as much as mine: we're both in reside

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Packed in, like the poor, three to a bed.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Did you love Henry -- ever?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Ever? Back before the flood?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: As long ago as Rosamund.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Rising from the floor) Ah, that's pre-history, lamb; there are no written record survivors.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: There are pictures. She was prettier than you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (She moves to the rack where HENRY'S clothes hang, runs her hand absently among them) Oh, much. Her eyes in certain light were violet and all h teeth were even. That's a rare feature, even teeth. She smiled to excess but she chewed with real distinction. (Cut to ALAIS)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: And you hate her even now. (Cut to ELEANOR as she moves across the room toward HENRY'S bed)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No ... but I did. He put her in my place, you see, and th was very hard. Like you, she headed Henry's table: that's chair.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: if t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 92 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: And so you had her poisoned. (She settles on a corner of the bed)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That's a folktale. Oh, I prayed for her to drop and sang little when she did but even Circe had her limits. Why ar you happy? Henry's keeping you. You must be cleverer than am. (Cut to ALAIS moving toward ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I've tried feeling pity for you but it keeps on turning i something else.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Cut to ELEANOR looking up as ALAIS moves into the picture) Why pity?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You love Henry but you love his kingdom, too. You look at and you see cities, acreage, coastline, taxes. All I see Henry. Leave him to me, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: But I left him years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: And I thought I could move you. Were you always like this Years ago, when I was young and worshipped you, is this w you were like?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Most likely. Child, I'm finished and I've come to give hi anything he asks for.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Do you know what I should like for Christmas? I should to you suffer. (Cut to ELEANOR, close up. Nodding as the suffering shows on her face)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Alais, just for you. (Cut to ALAIS, close up. She understands and all the love and tenderness she used to feel for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 Continued ELEANOR comes flooding back. With a small cry, she throws herself into ELEANOR'S arms. ELEANOR holds her, rocks her, like a child, gently back and forth)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Maman, oh Maman.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Alors, ma petite.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: J'ai peur, Maman.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Taking up the little song in the middle) «+. the Christmas logs will glow, There's Christmas cheer and comfort here -- (Something catches her eye. She stops singing, turns. (Cut to HENRY standing in the doorway. He sees them but he doesn't really take them in. His manner is brisk, keyed high, with a kind of mad energy)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The sky is pocked with stars. What eyes the wise men must had to spot a new one in so many. (Cut to ELEANOR & ALAIS as ALAIS rises and moves to the wine pot on the brazier)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You look cold.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I've mulled some wine. (Cut to HENRY, moving into the room)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I wonder, were there fewer stars then -- I don't know. I fancy there's a mystery in it. (ALAIS moves into the picture with a goblet of wine) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 94 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Warm wine. Why You oft Let She You She

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: so it is. (He takes the wine, touches her cheek) are as beautiful as I remembered. (Sending her toward the door) to bed. My widow wants to see me. (ALAIS goes to the door, stops, turns back)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: me stay. (Cut to HENRY, shaking his head. Cut back to

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: came to find out what your plans are. She wants you back. (ALAIS starts to say more, stops, turns sharply and goes. (Cut to HENRY & ELEANOR. She is still on the bed. He is at the brazier, pouring wine)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: do?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: thinks I do. She thinks the need for loving never stops.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: She's got a point. I marvel at you. After all these years still like a democratic drawbridge, going down for everyb (He moves to her with a goblet for each of them)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: At my age, there's not much traffic any more. (He hands her a goblet, raises his in a toast)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: To your interminable health. (He drinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 95 Continued HENRY (Cont) Well, wife, what's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh Henry, we have made a mess of it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yes, haven't we. You look like Doomsday.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Late nights do that to me. Am I puffy? (We follow HENRY as he strolls to the fireplace)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Possibly: it's hard to tell -- there's all that natural s (Cut to ELEANOR, close up)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I've just seen Richard. (Cut to HENRY, close up. He faces the fire, his back to her. His face reacts but his voice shows nothing of it)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Splendid boy. (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: He says you fought. (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We always do. (Cut to a view of both of them)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's his impression that you plan to disinherit them.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I fancy I'll relent. Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I don't much care. (Cut to HENRY close up as he turns sharply to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 Continued O (Cut back to view of both of them) In fact I wonder, Henry, if I care for anything. I wonder 5 I'm hurt out of habit and if all my lusts, like passion poem aren't really recollections.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I could listen to you lie for hours. So your lust is rust Gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Henry, I'm so tired. (HENRY leaves the fireplace, starts moving toward her)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Sleep, then. Sleep and dream of me with croutons. Henri a mode de Caen. (As he reaches her, she rises with a surge of energy)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: So Henry, stop it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Eleanor, I haven't started.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What is it you want? You want my name on paper, I'll sign anything. You want the Aquitaine for John? It's John's. I his, it's yours, it's anybody's.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: In exchange for what? (Cut to ELEANOR, close up)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: For nothing, for a little quiet, for an end to this, for sake, sail me back to England, lock me up and lose the ke let me be alone. (Cut to HENRY. He nods appreciatively. Then, raising his hands, he starts to applaud. (Cut to ELEANOR as the applause grows louder and louder) ( a You have my oath. I give my word. 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued (Cut to both of them. The applause grows thunderous, then cuts off abruptly. Bone weary, nodding, ELEANOR sinks into a chair) Oh, well. Well, well. (HENRY circles her like a dog that's trapped its prey)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Would you like a pillow? Footstool? How about a shawl? Yo oaths are all profanities. Your word's a curse. Your name paper is a waste of pulp. (She is not reacting. He bends towards her, bellowing) I'm vilifying you, for God's sake. Pay attention. (She looks up, only half seeing. She reaches out and takes his hand and kisses it. He pulls his hand sharply away)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Like any thinking person, I should like to think there wa don't care whose or which -- some God. Not out of fear: d is a lark, it's life that stings. But if there were some then I'd exist in his imagination, like Antigone in Sopho I'd have no contradictions, no confusions, no waste parts misplaced elements and then, oh Henry, then I'd make some sense. I'd be a Queen in Arcady and not an animal in chao How, from where we started, did we ever reach this Christ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step by step.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What happens to me now? (We follow HENRY as he moves to his bed)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That's lively curiosity from such a dead cat. If you want know my plans, just ask me. (Cut to ELEANOR, rising, with a surge of anger)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Conquer China, sack the vatican or take the veil. I'm not among the ones who give a damn. Just let me sign my lands John and go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 98 Continued (Cut to HENRY as he stretches out luxuriously)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No, you're too kind. I can't accept. (Cut to ELEANOR. She moves to the bed, glares down at him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Come on, man. I'll sign the thing in blood or spit or bri blue ink. Let's have it done.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Let's not. No, I don't think I want your signature on anything.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dear God, the pleasure I still get from goading you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You don't want John to have my provinces?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Bull's eye. (She bends down over him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I can't bear you when you're smug. (HENRY grins up at her, reveling in it)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I know, I know. (She straightens up, draws slightly back)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You don't want Richard and you don't want John.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY -
dialogues.text: You've grasped it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: All right, let me have it. Level me. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (He sits up. Savoring each syllable) A new wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 99 Continued (Cut to ELEANOR, close up. She is utterly dismayed)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh. (She sits slowly and carefully on the bed. HENRY rises, stands over her)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Aesthete and poetaster that you are, you worship beauty a simplicity. I worship with you. Down with all that's ugly complex -- like frogs or pestilence or our relationship. you, what's more beautiful and simple than a new wife? (Cut back to ELEANOR who, assembling herself bravely, asks - )

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: So I'm to be annulled. Well, will the Pope annul me, do y think? (Cut to HENRY, wine goblet in hand)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The Pontiff owes me one Pontificate. I think he will. (Cut to ELEANOR still on the bed)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Out Eleanor, in Alais. Why? (Cut to HENRY. vehemently as he starts back to her)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: A new wife, wife, will bear me sons. (Cut to ELEANOR as she rises and moves to meet him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That is the single thing of which I should have thought y enough. (They stand face to face)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I want a son.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Whatever for? Why we could populate a country town with country girls who've borne you sons. How many is it? Help count the bastards. i ij i i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ak  76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: All my sons are bastards.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You really mean to do it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Lady love, with all my heart. (HENRY turns away from her, moves energetically to a narrow slit of a window, stands with his back to her, looking out)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Your sons are part of you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Like warts and goiters; and I'm having them removed.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: We made them. They're our boys. (Cut to HENRY from the front. ELEANOR is in the background, behind him. All the grief is in his face, none in his voice)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I know -- and good God, look at them. Young Henry: vain, deceitful, weak and cowardly. The only patriotic thing he ever did was die.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I thought you loved him most.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I did. (He turns to face her) And Geoffrey -- there's a masterpiece. He isn't fresh: he device: he's wheels and gears. (ELEANOR sits in one of a pair of arm chairs)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Every family has one. (HENRY moves to her, sits in the other chair)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But not four. Then Johnny. Was his latest treason your id

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 Continued (Not facing him, she shakes her head) HENRY (Cont) I have caught him lying and I've said he's young. I've se his cheating and I've thought he's just a boy. I've watch him sin and whore and whip his servants and he's not a ch He is a man we've made him.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don't share John with me. He's your accomplishment.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: And Richard's yours. How could you send him off to deal w Philip.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I was tired. I was busy. They were friends.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (He rises, looks down at her) Eleanor, he was the best. The strongest, bravest, handsom and from the cradle on you cradled him. I never had a cha

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Rising to face him) You never wanted one.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How do you know? You took him. Separation from your husba you could bear. But not your boy.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Whatever I have done, you made me do. HENRY . You threw me out of bed for Richard.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Not until you threw me out for Rosamund.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's not that simple. I won't have it be that simple.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I adored you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 102 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I still do. (Cut to HENRY, close up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Of all the lies, that one is the most terrible. (Cut to ELEANOR close up)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I know: that's why I saved it up for now. (Cut to HENRY close up, eyes blazing. (Cut to ELEANOR close up, burning with defiance. (Cut to include both as, after one more immobile moment, they throw themselves into each other's arms. They hold light, wanting shelter from the storm they've made) Oh, Henry, we have mangled everything we've touched.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Deny us what you will, we have done that. (He pulls away from her, looks gently down into her face) Do you remember when we met?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Looking radiantly up at him) Down to the hour and the color of your stockings.

dialogues.speaker: . HENRY
dialogues.text: I could hardly see you for the sunlight. (She sits at the foot of the bed. He settles on the floor, rests his head on her lap)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It was raining but no matter.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There was very little talk as I recall it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: very little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I had never seen such beauty and I walked right up and to it. God, where did I find the gall to do that? (She bends tenderly down)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: In my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I loved you. (They kiss, then gently part, each lost in reverie)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No annulment.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: There will be no annulment.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Will there not?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid you'll have to do without.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Anger just bottled in, getting to his feet) Well -- it was just a whim.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'm so relieved. I didn't want to lose you. HENRY . (He starts to pace. We pull back, including them both) Out of curiosity, as intellectual to intellectual, how in name of bleeding Jesus can you lose me? Do you ever see m Am I with you? Ever near you? Am I ever anywhere but somewhere else? (Cut to ELEANOR, close up, delighted. HENRY leans forward into the picture) Do we write? Do I send messages? Do dinghies bearing gift float up the Thames to you? Are you remembered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 104 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're no part of me. We do not touch at any point. How c you lose me?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Can't you feel the chains?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You know enough to know I can't be stopped.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: but I don't have to stop you. I have only to delay you. E enemy you have has friends in Rome. We'll cost you time.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What is this? I'm not moldering: my paint's not peeling o I'm good for years.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How many years? Suppose I hold you back for one: I can -- possible. Suppose your first son dies, ours did -- it's possible. Suppose you're daughtered next. We were -- that too, is possible. How old is Daddy then? (Cut to HENRY looking grim. Then back to ELEANOR) What kind of spindly, ricket-ridden, milky, semi-witted, wizened, dim-eyed, gammy-handed, limpy line of things wil beget? (Cut to HENRY looking grimmer)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's sweet of you to care. (Cut back to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR 5
dialogues.text: And when you die, which is regrettable but necessary, wha happen to frail Alais and her pruney prince? you can't th Richard's going to wait for your grotesque to grow. (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You wouldn't let him do a thing like that? (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Let him? I'd push him through the nursery door. (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You're not that cruel. (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don't fret. We'll wait until you're dead to do it. (HENRY moves to her, into the picture)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Eleanor, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Circling him as earlier he circled her) Just what you want, a king for a son. You can make more. can't. You think I want to disappear. One son is all I've and you can blot him out and call me cruel. For these ten years you've lived with everything I've lost and loved an woman through it all. And I'm cruel. I could peel you lik pear and God himself would call it justice. Nothing I cou to you is wanton. Nothing is too much. (Cut to ELEANOR moving down the corridor toward him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You go to Rome, we'll rise against you. (Cut to HENRY as ELEANOR moves into the picture)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Who will?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Richard, Geoffrey, John and Eleanor of Aquitaine.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The day those stout hearts band together is the day that get wings.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: There'll be pork in the treetops come the morning. Don't you see: You've given them a common cause: new sons. You the country and you've lost it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 106 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: All of you at once.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And Philip, too. He'd join us.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yes, he would. (Cut to ELEANOR, close up, on top again)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Now how's your trip to Rome? (Cut to HENRY, cornered, beaten. Voice over) Oh, I've got you, got you, got you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Should I take a thousand men-at-arms or is that showy? (Cut to ELEANOR from behind HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Bluff away. I love it. (He starts moving forward toward her. She begins retreating. We keep with them as they edge their way back into the bedroom)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Ah, poor thing. How can I break the news? You've just miscalculated.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Have I? How? ,

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
