dialogues.text: You should have lied to me. You should have promised to b good while I was gone. I would have let your three boys l They could have fought me then.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You wouldn't keep your sons locked up here?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why the devil wouldn't I? (Cut to ELEANOR, close up, desperate)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You don't dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 Continued (Cut to HENRY, unstoppable, victorious)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why not? What's to stop me? Let them sit in Chinon for a while. (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I forbid it! (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: She forbids it! (Cut to HENRY from ELEANOR'S POV. He storms toward the door. (Cut to the room from the corridor. HENRY moves towards us, ELEANOR in the background) (Cut to ELEANOR, close up)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Did your father sleep with me or didn't he? (HENRY, close to camera, stops. Color drains from his face. It is a thought he cannot bear. He turns toward her)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No doubt you're going to tell me that he did. (Cut to ELEANOR from HENRY'S POV)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Would it upset you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Moving into the picture, stalking toward ELEANOR) What about the thousand men? I say be gaudy and to hell w it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don't leave me, Henry. I'm at rock bottom. I'11 do anythi to keep you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I think you think you mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: or, 76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 Continued (We see them both, their faces close together)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Ask for something.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Eleanor, we're past it; years past.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Test me. Name an act.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There isn't one.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: About my fornication with your father -- (We pull back slightly as HENRY moves forward and ELEANOR steps backward. She finds herself against the foot of the bed)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yes there is. You can expire.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR 1
dialogues.text: you first, old man. I only hope I'm there to watch. You'r afraid of dying. You're so scared of it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Poor Eleanor; if only she had lied.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (She sits on the bed, starts to stretch out) She did. She said she never loved your father.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can always count on.you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I never touched you without thinking "Geoffrey, Geoffrey. (Cut to HENRY from ELEANOR'S POV. He is on the bed, crouched over her)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: When you hurt me, I'll cry out. (Cut to ELEANOR from HENRY'S POV, on her back on the bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I've put more horns on you than Louis ever wore. (Cut to show them both; she on the bed, he crouched over her)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to care?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'll kill you if you leave me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You can try. (She leans up, close to him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I loved your father's body. He was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Retreating from the impact of it, sitting on the edge of the bed, turning away from her) It never happened.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I can see his body now. Shall I describe it?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Eleanor, I hope you die. (She rises to her knees on the bed, seeming to tower over him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: His arms were rough, with scars here --

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I can feel his arms. I feel them.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Crying out) Aahbhh! (Cut to ELEANOR. Close up, just her face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 76 Continued

dialogues.speaker: O ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What's that? Have I hurt you? (Cut to include both of them on the bed)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I'm going to be sick. (We follow him from the doorway as he rises, starts for the camera. (Cut to ELEANOR. Carried away, hurling it after him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: We did it! You were in the next room when he did it. (Cut to doorway again as HENRY moves past the camera into the corridor. Then, slowly we move across the room, closer and closer to ELEANOR. Her face is a picture of total desolation) Well, what family doesn't have its ups and downs) a . (She rises from the bed) It's cold. (She sees the brazier, moves it, huddles down to it for warmth) I can't feel anything. Not anything at all. (Her hands and face are close to the coals. We move closer and closer) We couldn't go back, could we, Henry. (We fade slowly on her desolate and anguished face. The moment we reach black -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to close up of a great hand slapping down with tremendous impact on the buttocks of a body asleep in bed. there is a howl of surprised pain as the body bolts upright and we pull back to reveal - (HENRY, a flaming torch in hand, looming over WILLIAM MARSHAL who is wide awake, naked to the waist in bed. HENRY is bursting with energy, his eyes bright.

dialogues.speaker: STONE BARRACK ROOM
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY, torch in hand, striding down a crude stone barracks room. Sleeping soldiers in uniforms lie on the floor. MARSHAL follows HENRY along)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (More a great bellow than a word) Hey - hey - hey. When INT. INT. INT. INT. INT. INT. (General stirring as SOLDIERS wake up) the King is off his ass, nobody sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: (Cut to a SQUAD OF SOLDIERS, MARSHAL in command, striding down a corridor. They halt beside a door.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: (Cut to interior of the room. JOHN & a pathetic SERVANT GIRL are in bed, covered up, naked. JOHN is asleep, his head on her breast. She is awake, pathetic eyes staring sadly at nothing)

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: (Cut to the corridor. MARSHAL gestures an order. TWO SOLDIERS break ranks, move to the door. MARSHAL gestures again and the SQUAD moves down the corridor)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: (Cut to JOHN & THE GIRL. She sees something, gasps in fear as rough hands appear in the picture. The hands hurl back the blankets. JOHN'S eyes fly open. His scream of terror is cut off as a hand covers his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY'S ROOM
dialogues.text: (Cut to GEOFFREY asleep. He starts, eyes open, all at once wide awake. SOLDIERS appear by his bed. He licks his lips, looks at them, scared to death)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD'S ROOM
dialogues.text: (Cut to RICHARD, from the waist up. Naked, dagger in hand, he stands crouching, pressed against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 (Cut to FOUR SOLDIERS, swords drawn, from RICHARD'S POV. MARSHAL steps from the shadows, joins them. (Cut to RICHARD as he drops his dagger.)

dialogues.speaker: DUNGEONS
dialogues.text: (A heavy dungeon-like door is seen in near darkness. It stands in a shallow recess along a dim stone corridor that curves concavely. Hands appear, hurling the door open. (RICHARD, JOHN & GEOFFREY move stiffly through the door. MARSHAL himself closes and bolts it with considerable clanging of chains and locks. (Cut to RICHARD, JOHN & GEOFFREY huddled in the dark, listening to the clanging) (Cut to MARSHAL as he hands keys to a fierce, enormous SOLDIER. As MARSHAL and his MEN move off, the SOLDIER takes up his position in the recess. (Cut to RICHARD, JOHN & GEOFFREY in the dark as they begin to peer about. (Cut to the place from their POV. It is dark, all shadows, cavernous and vast but hard to make out. A faint gleam of light glows in the distance. (Cut to RICHARD, JOHN & GEOFFREY as they start toward the light. (Cut to them as they reach the source of the light. They look around. They are in a large, dank vaulted room off which many corridors go. Casks of wine line the walls of the room. they are in the wine cellar. Candles burn. (Cut to their faces, close up. Each of them, in his own way is terribly afraid)

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY as, with his torch, he strides into the vast kitchen of the castle. MARSHAL follows after him. Fires glow in fireplaces. VASSALS lie asleep on the floor amidst carcasses of beef and poultry and the day's debris. HENRY strides among them, kicking them awake)

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY, striding through the poultry yard outside, kicking chickens, ducks and geese awake. The CHICKEN KEEPER, half asleep, stands listening to orders from MARSHAL. There is much honking and squawking) (Cut to HENRY, close up, bending over coals at the SMITH'S forge. His energy seems manic; sweat pours off his face. He is looking at a glowing piece of metal, part of a suit of armor. The ARMORER brings his hammer crashing down. (Cut to HENRY striding across the courtyard. All about him, shadowy figures are stirring. MEN are pushing a heavy wagon. Horses neigh. Still with his torch, he pauses, looks up at a tower. (Cut to the TOWER from HENRY'S POV. He is looking at a window)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR'S ROOM
dialogues.text: (Cut to ELEANOR. She lies fully clothed on her bed, moonlight from the window striking the pillow near her head. She is wide awake, motionless. Her eyes stare unblinking. Her face looks ravaged. Hubbub from the yard rises in pitch. Slowly, she gets up, crosses to the window. She stands there, moonlight on her face, her face a mask, looking out)

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: (Cut to the Courtyard from ELEANOR'S POV. The ACTORS, bleary from no sleep, are staggering about loading up their props and costumes. The hubbub increases as more and more figures appear, scurrying about through the dimness and shadows. MARSHAL moves among them, busy supervising) (Cut to SERVANTS busily packing silver plates and jeweled goblets into traveling cases. HENRY, torch held high, stands over them) (Cut to SERVANTS pushing a great barrel up an incline into a wagon. HENRY is there, urging them on. More wagons appear. More SERVANTS, more SOLDIERS, more boxes and crates. From this crescendo of activity ~ )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the dim, grim silence of the wine cellar. We see rough, damp, dripping stone wall in flickering light. We follow the wall down and, as we reach the floor, discover JOHN & RICHARD. (THEY are sitting on the floor, a candle between them. Behind them is a wine barrel. They are drinking. As we pull back, we see GEOFFREY standing a bit apart from them)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What I say is we might as well be drunk.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: ‘If I were you, I'd worry.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: you know me. I'd only worry over all the wrong things.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The fortress at Vaudreuil has dungeons down two hundred f If I were Father, that's the place I'd keep us.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: And if I were Father, I'm not sure I'd keep the three of all. (He crouches down beside them. To RICHARD) You don't take prisoners, no you don't. And with good rea Dungeon doors can swing both ways but caskets have no hin

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I know you. You only want to frighten me. (We see just their three faces, pale and tense in the dark)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: John, the condition of your trousers, be they wet or dry, not concern me less. I think I'm apt to die today and I a sweating, John. I'm sweating cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY'S face close up. Smudged, dirty, bathed in sweat. We pull back to see him lurching across a section of courtyard, a heavy treasure chest on his shoulder. (TWO SOLDIERS take it from him and hoist it onto a heavily armored wagon. HENRY straightens, looks up at the sky. i i i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 Continued (Dawn is about 45 minutes away. The sky is lightening a little. He looks up at ELEANOR'S window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to ELEANOR at the window, as we saw her last, looking out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY in the courtyard, seen from above. The yard is a mass of wagons, horses, SERVANTS & SOLDIERS, torches. HENRY grins up at the window and blows a kiss. (Cut to ELEANOR as, with sudden decision, she leaves the window and crosses her room toward the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY striding across the courtyard towards the kitchen. He pauses by the open shed where the baking ovens are, sniffs in the aroma of the morning's bread and nods appreciatively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to ELEANOR moving along a corridor. the wall torches have long since gutted out. the only light comes from a small torch carried by the One-Armed GUARD who follows at a polite distance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY striding from the courtyard into the kitchen. It is a scene of frenetic activity now. Sides of beef turn on spits over roaring fires. Animals were slaughtered in the kitchens at this time and in a corner, slaughtering is going on. VASSALS, cleaning the floor are sweeping offal and god knows what into an open trench that cuts across the floor. Great kettles boil. There is steam and sweat. (HENRY moves briskly about, approving here, correcting there. His spirits are frighteningly high)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the Parlor door from the inside as it opens out. ELEANOR moves through. The only light is the dim, distorting flicker of her GUARD'S torch. He remains by the doorway as she moves toward the Christmas tree. Near it, she stops, eyes bright, looking thoughtfully at the presents underneath the tree)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY striding down a corridor. He reaches a door, throws it open. HENRY, close up, looks a little mad. His eyes are red, his forehead dirty and dripping with sweat. He is vibrating with nervous energy. cur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He crosses the room, throws open a curtain. Dawn is half an hour off; the light is dim and cold. He turns and looks at - (ALAIS. Dressed as we saw her last, she is curled up asleep in a chair. She starts awake)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Henry? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Moving to her, into the picture) We're packing up and moving out.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Is there a war? What's happened? (He throws his arms around her in a great bear hug) Henry, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Nothing, for a change. Would you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Where've you been all night?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Out making us an entourage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 117 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We're off to Rome to see the Pope.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: He's excommunicated you again.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He's going to set me free. I'm having Eleanor annulled. T nation will be shocked to learn our marriage wasn't consummated.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Oh, be serious.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I am. It seems that you and I are getting married. (Cut to ALAIS. She can't believe it. Then back to both of them) By the Pope himself.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You mean it?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Shall I kneel?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: It's not another trick?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The bridal party's drilling on the cobblestones. (We follow ALAIS as she runs to the window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to the courtyard from ALAIS'S POV. The havoc of the night taking shape. Wagons stand in some semblance of order. Troops move about)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: (Voice over) She still loves you, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Voice over) So she ‘says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to ALAIS as she leaves the window, moves to

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: She'll find a way to stop us.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How? She won't be here. We're launching her for Salisbury Tower when the winds change. She'll be barging down the R Vienne by lunchtime.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: If she doesn't stop us, Richard will.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Not any more. I've corked him up. He's in the cellar with brothers and the wine. The royal boys are aging with the port. You haven't said yes. Would you like a formal decla tion? (He goes to one knee, turning his profile to us) There -- my finest angle; it's on all the coins. Sad Alai will you marry me? (She looks down at him lovingly) Be my Queen. (She goes down to him, melts in his arms. He kisses her cheeks, her hands, her neck) We'll love each other and you'll give me sons. Let's have -- we'll do Eleanor one better. Why, I'll even call the f one Louis, if you like Louis le Premier: how's that for a of England? (They start to laugh. They try to kiss but both of them are laughing. Gradually, as HENRY roars on, her laughter subsides, then stops, all joy fading from her face)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Henry -- you can't ever let them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 119 Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Laughter subsiding) You've lost me. Let who out?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Your sons. You've put them in the dungeon and you've got keep them there forever.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Do I now?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: If they're free when you die, it's the dungeon or the nun for me. I don't care which -- a cell's a cell -- but, Hen what about the child.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Anger beginning, he gets to his feet) Don't bother me about the child. The damn thing isn't bor yet. (Cut to ALAIS, close up, as she rises)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: If they're free, they'll kill it. I'm the one who'll live see that. I will not live to see our children murdered. (Cut to HENRY as he turns angrily to face her)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You don't make the ultimatums. I do. (Cut to ALAIS as she bears down on him)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Not this time. You either keep them down forever or you g yourself another widow. I don't want the job.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: My boys -- how can I?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: That's for you to face.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You have no children. (Cut to ALAIS close up) a I tna A ETT LT er steeTete th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 110 120 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: And I never will. (Cut to HENRY close up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But they're my sons. (Cut to ALAIS close up)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I hate your sons. I'm not the one who wants a new line. I you want it that's the price. (Cut to HENRY close up)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You'll come to Rome if I say so. You'll marry me if I say The boys go free if I say so. My terms are the only terms (Sitting, energy ebbing, dazed and spent) The difficulty is, you see, the difficulty is, you're rig Incredible, but I have children who would murder children Every time I've been to Medea, I've thought, "No; the thi absurd. Fish eat their young, and foxes; but not us." And she did it. (He pulls himself to his feet, starts moving heavily toward the door, passing ALAIS as he goes) I imagine she was mad, don't you? Yes, mad she must have

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Henry? (Near the door, he stops. She moves to him) Are you going down? (He nods) To let them out or keep them in?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Could you say to a child of yours, "You've seen the sunli for the last time"?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Can you do it, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 Ae a ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (With sudden anger as he turns and storms out of the room) I shall have to, shan't I? INT. EXT. INT. INT. (Cut to ALAIS watching him go, both elated and aghast at what she has accomplished. She hesitates, then runs out of the room after him)

dialogues.speaker: GREAT HALL
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY storming through the Great Hall. NOBLES in modest numbers are at the tables eating. They rise and bow as HENRY moves past them. Acknowledging none of it, he strides straight on.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY bounding down the broad stone steps to the courtyard. He passes the camera, moving out of the picture as ALAIS appears at the top of the steps, hesitates again, then hurries after him. Dawn is 15 minutes off. The light is stronger and the day is going to be clear) (The camera turns and we watch them moving through the yard. The GROUP OF CAROLERS wanders blearily in the picture; it's a bit too early in the day for singing. We lose HENRY and ALAIS as, for a moment, we follow the CAROLERS along, leaving them as we pick up on ELEANOR in a corner of the yard. She carries a biggish Christmas present which, had we time to view it closely, would look the least bit hastily rewrapped. Her GUARD follows along behind)

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDORS
dialogues.text: (Cut to ELEANOR going down a flight of stone steps moving from daylight into gloom. Her GUARD follows. (Cut to ELEANOR moving down a dark twisting corridor. She reaches another flight of steps, starts down. Her GUARD follows)

dialogues.speaker: DUNGEONS AND CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: (Cut to the wine Cellar door. The SOLDIER stands by it in the recess, alert. We pull back, taking in the curve of the corridor. ELEANOR rounds the curve, stops and draws back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 116 Continued QO) (Cut to ELEANOR in shadows. She turns to her GUARD. He is very close to her now. She nods. They exchange a look of understanding. The GUARD draws a short, blunt, heavy dagger and starts stealthily forward. (We see them all: ELEANOR tensely watching; her GUARD edging forward, pressed along the curving wall; the SOLDIER in the recess, unaware but listening. , (Eleanor's GUARD stops just before the recess. He crouches, ready to leap. Both he and the SOLDIER wear armor from the waist up. The GUARD raises dagger. His armor squeaks. (The SOLDIER spins at the sound. The GUARD leaps. His knife flashes down, glancing harmlessly on the SOLDIER'S armor. (They face each other in the confines of the recess. There is no room. They feint, armor making the moves heavy and slow. The SOLDIER lunges. His dagger slides and scrapes along the - GUARD'S armor, searching for a point of entry. Oo The only sounds are natural ones: grunts, heavy breathing, the clank and rattle of armor, the squeal of dagger points on steel. (It's all so clumsy. Every move is graceless. Nothing works. The walls keep getting in the way. they wheeze and stumble. It is ludicrous -- and it is this that gives the fight its special horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Eleanor's GUARD is thrown clear of the recess. He ) lunges back. They fall, rolling and clanking about i in the shadowed niche. Slow-moving arms and ) thrashing legs. ! (We pull back to include ELEANOR. She wills herself to watch. There is a strangled cry. One ) pair of legs goes into spasm. She goes on watching as her GUARD rises, keys to the door in hand. i (Cut to the Wine Cellar. JOHN, RICHARD & GEOFFREY | are where we saw them last. JOHN lies sprawled out, asleep. RICHARD, apparently placid, lies starting at nothing. GEOFFREY sits, tense, his face a picture of concentration. The tiny candle on the floor is guttering out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 Continued O (Echoing down long corridors comes the distinct rattle of chains and bolts on the cellar door. JOHN wakes with a start. The others stiffen. (Cut to ELEANOR passing through the cellar door. Her GUARD, now wearing enough of the dead SOLDIER'S uniform to pass for a soldier himself, closes the door and stands by it, guard-like. (Cut back to the boys. They exchange looks as the sound of the closing door reverberates and dies. RICHARD is the first to rise)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: He's here. (The others get to their feet. There is nothing to say. RICHARD starts into a low, dark, twisting corridor. The others follow. (It is very dark. The corridor curves and curves. We follow as they twist along. ' (Softly, really to himself, RICHARD mutters) o He'll get no satisfaction out of me. He isn't going to beg.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Why, you chivalric fool -- as if the way one fell down mattered.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: When the fall is all there is, it matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I (We lose them as they go around a corner. | (Cut to the three of them crouching along. Far ahead of them, we make out an area of brighter ' light. (Cut to RICHARD, the others just behind him, moving into brighter light. He registers surprise. (Cut to ELEANOR. She is standing in the center of the large room near the cellar door. Several candles flicker on the walls. She carries the Christmas present)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: C) My barge is leaving at eleven and I've come to say goo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 124 Continued

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Does Henry know you're here?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I've brought you each a little something.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: What's he planning?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Is he going to keep us here?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Moving toward a crude wooden table) I picked them out especially.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Mother -- (She slams the package down on the table. It makes a heavy, menacing metallic clatter. (Cut to RICHARD looking at ELEANOR. (Cut to RICHARD at the package, ripping off the ribbon and the wrapping, revealing a beautifully made small chest. He throws it open. We see a clutter of blunt, heavy, brutal looks daggers. (Cut to RICHARD as he strides toward ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How heavy is the outside guard?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That's taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What about the courtyard and the gates?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: They're putting Henry's train together and it's chaos. Yo walk right out.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (Moving to JOHN & GEOFFREY) We'll go to Poitiers. He'll expect that but we'll meet hi with an army when he comes. Keep close to me and when you run hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Why run at all? I think we ought to stay.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Stay here?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: 'Til Henry comes. (He turns toward ELEANOR. Cut to her. voice as -) He will come, won't he -- (Cut to GEOFFREY, turning back to his brother) --- and he'll come alone. I count three knives to one.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You think we could?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'd only do it wrong. You kill him and I'll watch.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: The three of us together. We must all three do it. (Cut to ELEANOR as she moves angrily to them)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him. Take the knives and run.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: And miss this opportunity?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (To RICHARD) I'll be behind the door with John. You'll want to do it f the back. (He turns to ELEANOR) And you, you lucky girl, you get to see the pageant.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You don't think I'm going to let this happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 126 Continued

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: If you tell, there'll be a rash of executions and you don want that. If you don't want to lose a one of us: not eve

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're clever but I wonder if you're right. (Just ELEANOR & GEOFFREY now, close up)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: You warn him, it's the end of us: you warn him not and it end of him. It's that clear.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Not very loud) Guard.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: Go on, dear. Call again and pitch it up a little.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'll have him take the knives away. (Cut to RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And be the one to put us in Vaudreuil, down two hundred f (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Then run away; escape. You've still got time. (Cut to RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. Geoffrey's right; we'll stay. (Cut to ELEANOR as she moves to RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You, too? Oh, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, oh. There's nothing in your "oh's": they're empty

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You're not an assassin. You're my Richard and you love me

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Let me kiss the nasty scratch and make it well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 116 127 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yes, do. Come let me hold you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You're more beautiful than ever. There is much that's beautiful if when it's absolutely pure. You are so foul y fair. You stand looking like a saint in pain when you bro us the knives to do you in.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (Striding to the knives) you did bring these things. (He picks one up, holds it out towards her) You want him dead, you do it. (Cut to ELEANOR, close up. Spitting it at him)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You unnatural animal. (Cut to RICHARD as he starts moving slowly toward ELEANOR. When he gets close to her, she starts edging away, back toward the dank stone walls. He follows, pressing her)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Unnatural, Mummy? You tell me, what's Nature's way? If poisoned mushrooms grow and babies come with crooked back goiters thrive and dogs go mad and wives kill husbands, w unnatural? Here stands your lamb. Come cover him with kisses. He's all yours.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No, you're not mine. I'm not responsible.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Where do you think I learned this from? Who do you think studied under? How old was I when you fought with Henry f

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Young ... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How many battles did I watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: But those were battles, not a knife behind a door.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I never heard a corpse ask how it got so cold. What were thinking when you fought with him? (She is against the wall now, pressed to the damp stones. He keeps moving in until their faces are inches apart)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Of you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: of your unnatural animal?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I did it all for you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You wanted Father dead.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No, never that.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You tried to kill him, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Why?! What did you want?!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I wanted Henry back. (It is an answer he cannot bear. He turns away, moving out of the picture)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You lie.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I wanted Henry. (She looks about, eyes on her children. (Cut to RICHARD, JOHN & GEOFFREY from ELEANOR'S POV. Voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 Continued ELEANOR (Cont) Isn't there a chair? (We follow JOHN as he moves to her and hands her a glass of wine)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Here. (ELEANOR takes the wine, then reaches out to touch his cheek. He draws away from her) None of that.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I've done without it this long. I'11l endure. (She raises the glass and drinks. (Cut to GEOFFREY as he moves to RICHARD)

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: She'll warn him. I was wrong. She'll do it if she gets th chance. (Cut to ELEANOR as, finding the strength from somewhere she advances on them)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Poor lambs; you don't dare let me stay here and you don't let me out. Dear me, whatever shall we do with Mother?

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: (Moving into the picture. With deadly intent) offhand, there are several possibilities. (The sound of chains and bolts being drawn on the door is clearly heard. GEOFFREY freezes. (Cut to the door as Eleanor's GUARD opens it. We see HENRY'S head only -- his face ashen, his eyes unblinking, fixed straight ahead -- as he passes through the door. ALAIS, holding a lighted taper, follows. (Cut to GEOFFREY who, recovering, turns to RICHARD. (Cut to RICHARD, looking toward GEOFFREY, ready to do the deed if GEOFFREY is. There is the sound of running. RICHARD turns.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 130 116 Continued (Cut to JOHN racing across the room to the table where he slams the lid of the chest down. (Cut to the cellar door as it slowly opens. HENRY appears, a load of large candles in his arms. ALAIS stands behind him, carrying a lighted taper. (HENRY steps into the room, looks about. With a brisk nod, he announces - )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It wants light. (He begins moving about the area, placing candles in empty candlesticks. ALAIS follows, lighting them with her taper. He doesn't seem to see his sons as he passes by them. They, however, are on wires, at. the brink, not quite sure how or when to make their move) What we do in dungeons needs the shades of day. I stole t candles from the chapel. No one minded. Jesus won't begru them and the Chaplain works for me. (He stops by ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You look dreadful.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So do you.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I underslept a little.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (We pull back, including them all, as HENRY deposits his last candle and steps back to survey the effect) We can all rest in a little while. That's better. Bright clear, just like the morning. (His eyes traveling from son to son, meaning it) Fine looking boy.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (striding angrily into the picture) What do you want from us? You must be mad. Why did you ha to come here? Damn you, why'd you come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 116 Continued 131

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You were the best. (Indicating ELEANOR) I told her so. You -- you, (To JOHN) I loved.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You're going to lock us up. (HENRY neither nods nor shakes his head) You've got to. You can't ever let me out ... You know you can't. I'll. never stop.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can't stop either. Brave boys. (RICHARD & HENRY stand, eyes locked. RICHARD turns sharply away, looks toward - (GEOFFREY, close up. He is white with tension. Will he do it? Won't he? (Cut to JOHN close up. He's terrified. (Cut to RICHARD as he flies across the room toward the tray. (Cut to HENRY as he draws his dagger. (Cut to RICHARD as he throws the chest open and grabs a dagger. He looks at - (GEOFFREY. He hasn't moved. Nor is he going to. (Cut to JOHN. He is ready to cry. (Cut to HENRY as he strides toward RICHARD. and chest)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That's what I've got. (At the chest, he picks up a dagger and tosses it to GEOFFREY. And another which he tosses to JOHN. (Cut to the sons.from HENRY'S POV. They are spread out in a semi-circle. They have daggers in hand but none of them moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 132 116 Continued (Cut to HENRY crouching, ready for them all, i wanting them all to come at him) | i

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come on. What is it? Come for me! } (Cut to a shot including them all. ALAIS, stiff with fear, stands pressed against a wall. ELEANOR, her face a mask, only her eyes alive, registers no change as - (HENRY starts slowly moving across the room toward RICHARD. He stops near him, crouching, his dagger held low, close, lethal. RICHARD makes no move) What's wrong? You're Richard, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: But you're Henry. (Cut to JOHN. He has backed off into a corner)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Daddy? Take me back? Please? Can't we try again? (Cut to HENRY, trying to take in the idea)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Again? (Cut to JOHN)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We always have before. (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes ... we always have. (Cut to JOHN seen from behind HENRY as, with a cry of joy, he drops his dagger and starts running across the room to his father, arms outstretched. He skids to a stop and crumples to the floor as HENRY, with a terrible animal sound, starts for him with his dagger. (Cut to JOHN from HENRY'S POV. He knows he's going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 133 Continued (Cut to HENRY from JOHN'S POV as HENRY, his face dreadful, goes to one knee, crouching over his son, ready to shove the dagger into JOHN'S vitals. The man is absolutely going to do the deed)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Voice over, sharp and commanding) Go on. (HENRY turns to look at her as she moves into the picture) Execute them. They're assassins, aren't they? this was treason wasn't it? You gave them life -- you take it. (They exchange a long look. Then HENRY'S eyes leave her and travel to his sons. (Cut to the sons from HENRY'S POV. They are hardly breathing, save for JOHN who is whimpering on the floor. (Cut to HENRY as his eyes return to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Who's to say it's monstrous? I'm the King. I call it just (HENRY turns from her and, alone now, draws his great sword and strikes a ritualistic, formal pose. His face shines with sweat and his eyes are mad) Therefore, I, Henry, by the grace of God, King of the Eng Lord of Scotland, Ireland and Wales. (Voice over as we move from JOHN as he makes little animal sounds of fear to GEOFFREY who believes he's done for but is still trying to think of a way out to RICHARD who is ready to die with dignity and style) Count of Anjou, Brittany, Poutou and Normandy, Maine, Gas and Aquitaine, do sentence you to death. (Cut back to HENRY still in his pose) Done this Christmas Day in Chinon in God's year Eleven Eighty-three. (As he lowers his sword, we cut back to see them all. In a formal, measured way, HENRY moves across the damp stone floor to RICHARD. It seems a long walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 134 116 Continued ) (Cut to HENRY & RICHARD, close, aS HENRY comes to a stop before him. RICHARD, eyes unswervingly on his father, stands motionless. HENRY slowly raises his sword -- higher, higher -- (With a howling cry, HENRY brings the sword whistles down, that edge against RICHARD'S shoulder. It makes a stinging slap-crack of a sound. (RICHARD staggers slightly, masking the pain as best he can, staring steadily at his father. { HENRY'S face is bewildered, as if he has lost contact for a moment not knowing where he is or what he's doing. (The moment hangs suspended as the camera moves to the other faces. JOHN still whimpers, unable to grasp what has happened. GEOFFREY, eyes bright with anticipation, is still waiting for the violence. ELEANOR'S face tells us nothing at all. ALAIS'S fear changes suddenly to concern as, with a little gasp, she steps forward, then stops herself. She is looking at - o) (HENRY as, spent and shattered, he sinks slowly to the floor. He sits there seeing nothing)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Surely that's not what I intended. Children ... children +e. they're all we have. (Unable to look at his sons, he waves them from the room) Go on. I'm done, I'm done, I'm finished with you. You and are finished. Never come again. (We draw back to take in his sons. GEOFFREY is the first to grasp what has happened. He gives a short sharp nod and starts into the shadows toward the cellar door. JOHN scurries after him. RICHARD hesitates -- as if he had something to say but can't -- then follows them out the door. (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You spare the rod, you'll spoil those boys. OC) (Cut to HENRY, huddled on the floor) f i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I couldn't do it, Eleanor. (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Nobody thought you could. (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I did. (Cut to ALAIS as she moves to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You saved them. You maneuvered it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Did I?

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: They're free because of you. They'll kill him one day; yo know that.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: The next time or the next.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You always win, maman.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Her gaze shifting toward HENRY) Except the prize. (Cut to HENRY wearily getting to his feet. ALAIS moves into the picture)

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: Come rest.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I want no women in my life.

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: You're tired.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I could have conquered Europe, all of it, but I had women life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 136 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALAIS
dialogues.text: I'll warm some wine.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've shot your world, you silly bitch, and there you stan honey and molasses. Sweet? You make my teeth ache. (And they are in each other's arms. (Cut to ELEANOR. It is more than she can bear to look at)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That's touching. Is it for my benefit? (We see all three of them as HENRY whirls angrily at her) :

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Your benefit? (To ALAIS, gruffly, not taking his eyes from

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Get out. Go on. Go. (ALAIS moves toward the door, out of the picture as HENRY, like a great cat, moves to ELEANOR) I should have killed you years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: There's no one peeking. Do it now.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've wasted fortunes, squandered lives, spent everything buy this pit. (He looks at it. Cut to the area from his POV. Voice over) I've got an eye for value. And I meant to do so much. (Cut to ELEANOR)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Is this a play for pity? (Cut to HENRY)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Not from you. You put me here. You made me do mad things. You've bled me. een! i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: aN 116 137 Continued (Cut to both of them)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Shoulder it yourself. Don't put it on my back. You've don what you have done and no one but yourself has made you d Pick it up and carry it, I can. My losses are my work.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What losses? I've been cheated, not you. I'm the one with nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Lost your life's work, have you? Provinces are nothing. L is dirt. (ELEANOR'S face, close up) I've lost you and I can't ever have you back again. (Cut back to both of them) You haven't suffered. I could take defeats like yours and laugh. I've done it. If you're broken, it's because you'r brittle. (Cut to her face, close up) You are all that I have ever loved. Christ, you don't kno what nothing. (A shudder passes through her, like a stab of physical pain) I want to die. (Cut to HENRY. Initial doubt is followed by terrible dismay)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You don't. (We pull back. She is doubled up by the intensity of it, scarcely able to stand)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I want to die.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'll hold you. (She shakes her head, edges away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 138 Continued HENRY (Cont) It might help.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: {Lacking the strength to stand, sinking to the floor) I want to die.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: {Going to one knee beside her) Let me do something, damn you. This is terrible.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Henry, I want to die.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You will, you know. Wait long enough and it'll happen.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Surprised by a smile she didn't expect) So it will. (He takes her hands. We start moving away from them, farther and farther until, at the end, they are two little figures huddled on the cold floor of a great dark place)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We're in the cellar and you're going back to prison and m is wasted and we've lost each other and you're smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's the way I register despair. There's everything in li but hope.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We have each other and for all I know, that's what hope i

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Cut to her, close up) We're jungle creatures, Henry, and the dark is all around (Her eyes range the room. (Cut to the room from her POV. We see shadows, dark places, hints of movement as if great rats were stirring. voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 117 139 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: In the corners, you can see the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (Voice over) And they can see ours. (Cut to HENRY as he rises to his feet, a picture of enormous strength and majesty) I'm a match for anything. Aren't you? (Cut to ELEANOR looking up at him with the most profound affection)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I should have been a great fool not to love you. (HENRY nods in brisk agreement, bends down, helps her up. They start toward the cellar door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cut to HENRY & ELEANOR as they reach the top of the stairs, emerging into the bright golden sunlight of the courtyard. The day is glorious. They pause for a moment, drinking it in. Then HENRY turns to her and says - )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come along; I'll see you to your ship.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Drawing back, not ready) So soon?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: There's always Easter Court.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You'll let me out for Easter?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come the Resurrection, you can strike me down again.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (Alive again, ready for anything) Perhaps I'll do it next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 117. Continued And perhaps you won't. 140

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It must be late and I don't want to miss the tide. 118

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (She sweeps past him and out into the courtyard. HENRY moves after her, quickly catching up. We follow them a moment, losing them among the men and wagons of Henry's entourage. MARSHAL, nearby, watches them disappear. (As they slip from view, we take in the yard. The day is glorious and the air is full of noises -- livestock, poultry, men shouting, caroling, church bells. Everyone we see -- peasants working, soldiers drilling, eating, roistering about -- is filled with vigor and life. (A horse rides roughly through the mob, brutally hurling people aside. It's RICHARD. At the Main Gate, he stops, turns back, looks long and hard at -- (JOHN who is having trouble mounting his horse in another part of the yard. Once in the saddle, JOHN glares back at RICHARD and, turning, sends another glare at -- (GEOFFREY who, in. another part of the yard, stands by his mount adjusting his cloak. GEOFFREY breaks into an engaging smile, tosses JOHN a salute, turns away and tosses another to -- (PHILIP who, looking very regal and grand, is mounted at the head of the orderly ranks of his retinue. PHILIP returns a courtly nod, turns and nods again at -- (RICHARD who wheels away and gallops dashingly off as -- (We pick up HENRY & ELEANOR emerging from the line of wagons near the Main Gate. They are talking : animatedly but there is too much noise and we are too far away to hear. (Cut to GUARDS lining the drawbridge at the Main Gate. They snap to attention as HENRY & ELEANOR i move past them, then past the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sf Le

dialogues.speaker: CASTLE
dialogues.text: (We turn, following them, as they move down to the wharf, toward ELEANOR'S ship. (Cut to HENRY & ELEANOR as they reach the bottom of the gangplank. They stop, face each other. She takes his hand and, bowing, kisses it. She starts to turn away to mount the gangplank when HENRY says - )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You know, I hope we never die.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I hope so, too.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You think there's any chance of it? (She smiles, then starts to laugh. He joins her in the laughter. The MUSIC rises as we begin to pull back and we cannot hear her reply. We can, however, see them talking as ELEANOR moves to the deck of the ship and takes up a position at the rail. (Cut to HENRY, waving, shouting toward the ship. (Cut to HENRY from ELEANOR'S POV. She is well out on the river and he stands on the wharf, the Main Gate of the castle behind him) (Cut to ALAIS, standing by the Main Gate, watching) {Cut to ELEANOR, still at the deck rail, watching) (Cut to HENRY. He turns and looks towards ALAIS, then turns to the river and looks towards ELEANOR. He throws his arms out in a gesture of animal vitality and joy) : (We rise higher and higher over Chinon, never quit losing sight of ALAIS walking by the gate. ELEANOR out on the water on her ship and HENRY, arms open to the world)
